[33m<cert_title>Machine Learning Statistical Foundations Professional Certificate by Wolfram Research<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcert_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Artificial Intelligence Foundations: Machine Learning<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>Machine learning is the most exciting branch of artificial intelligence. It allows systems to learn from data by identifying patterns and making decisions[0m
[33mwith little to no human intervention. In this course, you'll navigate the machine learning lifecycle by getting hands-on practice training your first machine learning [0m
[33mmodel. Join instructor Kesha Williams as she explores widely adopted machine learning methods: supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement. There's a focus on sourcing[0m
[33mand preparing data and selecting the best learning algorithm for your project. After training a model, learn to evaluate model performance using standard metrics. [0m
[33mFinally, Kesha shows you how to streamline the process by building a machine learning pipeline. If you're looking to understand the machine learning lifecycle and the [0m
[33msteps required to build systems, check out this course.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Machine Learning Foundations: Linear Algebra<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>Ever wondered what's really going on underneath a machine learning algorithm? The answer is linear algebra. Without it, machine learning can't exist. [0m
[33mLinear algebra is a prerequisite for understanding and creating nearly all machine learning algorithms, especially those that prop up neural networks, natural language[0m
[33mprocessing tools, and deep learning models.Join instructor Terezija Semenski for an in-depth exploration of the core concepts of linear algebra alongside the [0m
[33mtechniques needed to design and implement a successful machine learning algorithm. Discover the basics of vector arithmetic, vector norms, matrix properties, advanced [0m
[33moperations, matrix transformation, and algorithms like Google PageRank. By the end of this course, you'll be ready to take the principles of linear algebra and apply [0m
[33mthem to your next big machine learning project.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Machine Learning Foundations: Calculus<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>Studying artificial intelligence and machine learning can be difficult enough, but what if you threw some calculus into the mix? It may sound daunting, [0m
[33mbut understanding the foundations of calculus can help you design and implement machine learning algorithms, and without a solid foundation in calculus your work in [0m
[33mmachine learning can quickly become overwhelming.  In this course, Terezija Semenski teaches you functions, derivatives, integrals, and the foundations of multivariate[0m
[33mcalculus. If you struggle with calculus concepts and techniques used to design and implement ML algorithms, check out this course with Terezija for the knowledge to [0m
[33movercome those challenges.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Machine Learning Foundations: Probability<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description> If you work with machine learning models, you probably already know that your models are based on estimation and approximation. Probability is everything[0m
[33mand moreâ€”but how do you leverage it to your advantage?  In this course, the third part of the Machine Learning Foundations series, join instructor Terezija Semenski [0m
[33mfor an in-depth exploration of probability, its core concepts and functionalities, and how to use it to design, implement, and manage more reliable machine learning [0m
[33malgorithms. Along the way, discover some of the most essential tools and techniques you need to know for successful probabilistic modeling, pulling from the rules of [0m
[33mprobability, joint and marginal probability, discrete probability distributions, continuous probability distributions, Bayes' theorem, and more. <[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Machine Learning Foundations: Statistics<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>Machine learning models have revolutionized how we work, across a multitude of industries. But going deeper with ML models and actually understanding how [0m
[33mthey work will allow you to optimize performance, innovate, troubleshoot issues, and create new and more efficient ML models. In this course,  the fourth part of the [0m
[33m&lt;i&gt;Machine Learning Foundations&lt;[0m[33m/[0m[33mi[0m[33m&gt; series, Terezija Semenski explains how a deep understanding of statistics can help you excel when it comes to machine [0m
[33mlearning projects. Terezija shows how statistics plays a large role in machine learning â€”beyond just crunching numbersâ€”and shows you how to use statistics to gain [0m
[33minsights into the data, understand the uncertainties associated with predictions, and make data-driven decisions with confidence.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course>[0m
[33m<course_title>Built-in Machine Learning in the Wolfram Language<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>You can apply machine learning to diverse subject areas without expert-level knowledge with the help of Wolfram Language. While you can build complicated [0m
[33mmodels from scratch, you can also use any of the existing, pre-trained models on different inputs like text, numbers, and images. This course provides an introduction [0m
[33mto the many machine learning functions available for such wide-ranging tasks as image identification, text recognition, sentiment classification and others. Explore [0m
[33mthe automated machine learning capabilities of Wolfram Language through examples, and learn to execute simple machine learning tasks on different types of inputs, use [0m
[33mboth named and custom-trained models to perform classification tasks, and apply machine learning to computer vision, text, and natural language processing [0m
[33mtasks.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m

[1;32m─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36massistant:[0m
[34m# Curriculum Critique: Machine Learning Statistical Foundations Professional Certificate by Wolfram Research[0m

[34m## Overall Assessment[0m

[34mThis curriculum provides a structured approach to machine learning foundations with a focus on the mathematical underpinnings required for ML. The progression from [0m
[34mintroductory concepts to specialized mathematical domains [0m[1;34m([0m[34mlinear algebra, calculus, probability, and statistics[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m and finally to Wolfram-specific implementations is [0m
[34mlogical. However, there are several areas for improvement.[0m

[34m## Strengths[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Comprehensive Mathematical Foundation**: The curriculum properly emphasizes the critical mathematical disciplines that underpin machine learning.[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Clear Progression**: The sequence moves appropriately from general concepts to specific mathematical foundations before concluding with practical application in [0m
[34mWolfram.[0m

[1;34m3[0m[34m. **Instructor Consistency**: Having the same instructor [0m[1;34m([0m[34mTerezija Semenski[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m for the mathematical foundations courses likely provides consistency in teaching style [0m
[34mand approach.[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Theory-to-Application Connection**: The final course demonstrates how to apply theoretical knowledge using Wolfram Language.[0m

[34m## Areas for Improvement[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Lack of Practical Implementation in Foundation Courses**: The mathematical foundation courses appear to be heavily theoretical with insufficient information about[0m
[34mhow to implement these concepts in actual ML algorithms.[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Missing Intermediate Application**: There's a gap between the mathematical foundations and the final Wolfram-specific course. An intermediate course demonstrating[0m
[34mhow to apply these mathematical concepts in common ML algorithms would be beneficial.[0m

[1;34m3[0m[34m. **Limited Programming Context**: Beyond the final Wolfram course, there's little mention of programming skills or how mathematical concepts translate to code [0m
[34mimplementation.[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Minimal Coverage of Advanced ML Topics**: The curriculum lacks coverage of advanced topics like neural networks architecture, deep learning theory, or current [0m
[34mstate-of-the-art techniques.[0m

[1;34m5[0m[34m. **Software Dependency**: The curriculum seems heavily tied to Wolfram Language, which may limit students who wish to work with more broadly adopted frameworks like [0m
[34mPyTorch, TensorFlow, or scikit-learn.[0m

[1;34m6[0m[34m. **Limited Project-Based Learning**: There's insufficient emphasis on practical projects or capstone work that would allow students to integrate all concepts [0m
[34mlearned.[0m

[34m## Recommendations[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Add Implementation Components**: Include practical programming exercises in each mathematical foundation course that show how concepts directly apply to ML [0m
[34malgorithms.[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Introduce Framework-Agnostic ML Course**: Add a course between the foundations and Wolfram-specific course that teaches implementation using industry-standard [0m
[34mtools.[0m

[1;34m3[0m[34m. **Include Project-Based Learning**: Add a capstone project component that requires students to solve a real-world problem using the concepts learned.[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Expand Advanced Topics**: Consider adding a course on deep learning, reinforcement learning, or other advanced ML paradigms.[0m

[1;34m5[0m[34m. **Add Ethical Considerations**: Include content on ethics, bias, and responsible AI development throughout the curriculum.[0m

[1;34m6[0m[34m. **Practical Assessment Methods**: Clarify how students will be evaluated on their ability to apply these concepts, not just understand them theoretically.[0m

[34mThis curriculum provides a solid theoretical foundation but would benefit from stronger connections to practical implementation and industry-standard tools beyond the [0m
[34mWolfram ecosystem.[0m

[1;32m─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m

[1;32m─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36massistant:[0m
[34m# Audience Description: Machine Learning Statistical Foundations Professional Certificate by Wolfram Research[0m

[34m## Primary Target Audience[0m

[34mThis curriculum is designed for individuals who want to understand the mathematical and statistical foundations of machine learning, with a specific focus on [0m
[34mimplementation using Wolfram Language. The ideal candidates include:[0m

[34m### [0m[1;34m1[0m[34m. Technical Professionals Looking to Transition into ML[0m

[34mProfessionals with technical backgrounds in engineering, computer science, or related fields who want to develop expertise in machine learning but need to strengthen [0m
[34mtheir mathematical foundations before diving into advanced implementations.[0m

[34m### [0m[1;34m2[0m[34m. Data Analysts Seeking Advanced Skills[0m

[34mCurrent data analysts who have experience working with data but want to enhance their skills to build and optimize machine learning models rather than just using [0m
[34mpre-built tools.[0m

[34m### [0m[1;34m3[0m[34m. STEM Students and Academics[0m

[34mGraduate or advanced undergraduate students in STEM fields who are interested in machine learning from a theoretical perspective before applying concepts to practical [0m
[34mapplications.[0m

[34m### [0m[1;34m4[0m[34m. Wolfram Language Users[0m

[34mCurrent Wolfram Language users who want to leverage the platform's machine learning capabilities but need a stronger theoretical foundation to effectively implement [0m
[34mand optimize models.[0m

[34m## Prerequisites and Background Knowledge[0m

[34mThe ideal participant should have:[0m

[34m- Basic programming experience [0m[1;34m([0m[34mnot necessarily in Wolfram Language[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Undergraduate-level mathematics exposure [0m[1;34m([0m[34mthough the courses aim to rebuild and strengthen these foundations[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Basic understanding of data analysis concepts[0m
[34m- Interest in the theoretical underpinnings of machine learning, not just application[0m

[34m## What This Audience Seeks[0m

[34mThis audience is looking for:[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Deep Understanding**: They want to know not just how to implement machine learning algorithms but why they work and how to optimize them based on mathematical [0m
[34mprinciples.[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Mathematical Rigor**: They value rigorous mathematical explanations that will enable them to read and understand academic papers and advanced ML techniques.[0m

[1;34m3[0m[34m. **Practical Application**: While they appreciate theory, they want to see how these concepts translate to practical implementation, particularly in the Wolfram [0m
[34mecosystem.[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Career Advancement**: Many are seeking to advance or pivot their careers by developing specialized expertise in machine learning that goes beyond surface-level [0m
[34mimplementation.[0m

[34m## Not Ideal For[0m

[34mThis curriculum is likely not well-suited for:[0m

[34m- Complete beginners with no mathematical background[0m
[34m- Those seeking quick, practical implementation without theoretical understanding[0m
[34m- Individuals exclusively focused on Python-based ML frameworks who have no interest in the Wolfram ecosystem[0m
[34m- Those seeking advanced, specialized ML topics without first establishing strong foundations[0m

[34mThe curriculum appeals to learners who value understanding the [0m[34m"why"[0m[34m behind machine learning algorithms and are willing to invest time in building strong mathematical [0m
[34mfoundations to become more effective ML practitioners, particularly within the Wolfram Language environment.[0m

[33mlook at this curation of courses:   [0m[1;33m{[0m[1;33m{[0m[33msnapshot[0m[1;33m}[0m[1;33m}[0m[33m      What's the ideal order of courses here? Think in terms of the target audience and the proper [0m
[33mscaffolding of ideas from beginner to intermediate[0m

[33mshows how to turn this raw data into powerful insights, exploring best practices and methodologies for analyzing research data to inform and guide your [0m
[33mUX design projects. Amanda covers a framework for setting appropriate objectives for your research, as well as how to create hypotheses. She goes over [0m
[33mboth qualitative and quantitative data, highlighting their individual strengths as data sources, and shows how to analyze and draw conclusions from [0m
[33mqualitative data. Along the way, she shares practical examples and advice that can help you apply each concept in your own practice.<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m

[33mresearch so you can avoid common mistakes and analytic errors. Learn to identify the needs of your data sets and select the right tools and methods for [0m

[34mBased on the course descriptions and considering a progression from foundational concepts to more specialized techniques, here's the recommended [0m
[34msequence:[0m

[34m## Beginning Level [0m[1;34m([0m[34mFoundations[0m[1;34m)[0m
[1;34m1[0m[34m. **UX Foundations: Research**[0m
[34m   - Provides a comprehensive overview of UX research methodologies[0m
[34m   - Ideal starting point for beginners to understand the landscape[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **UX Research Methods: Interviewing**[0m
[34m   - Focuses on a fundamental research method[0m
[34m   - Builds on basic concepts with practical application[0m

[34m## Intermediate Level [0m[1;34m([0m[34mCore Methods[0m[1;34m)[0m
[1;34m3[0m[34m. **UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing**[0m
[34m   - Expands skills with specific testing methodologies[0m
[34m   - Natural progression after learning interviewing techniques[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Data-Driven Product Research and Design**[0m
[34m   - Introduces tools and workflows for research integration[0m
[34m   - Bridges foundational knowledge with practical implementation[0m

[1;34m5[0m[34m. **UX Foundations: Analyzing User Data**[0m

[34m   - Provides deeper analysis techniques[0m

[1;34m7[0m[34m. **UX Research: Overcoming Data Anxiety**[0m
[34m   - Addresses challenges in data analysis[0m
[34m   - Helps refine analytical skills and confidence[0m

[1;34m8[0m[34m. **Agile UX Research**[0m
[34m   - Applies UX research in specific development methodology[0m
[34m   - Represents culmination of skills in real-world context[0m

[34mThis sequence creates a logical learning path from understanding basic research concepts to specialized techniques, and finally to practical application [0m
[34min modern development environments.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36muser:[0m
[33mlook at this transcript from a video course:::::   [0m[1;33m<[0m[1;33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course_title>[0m
[33mUX Deep Dive: Usability Testing[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course_transcript>[0m
[33m# UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing[0m

[33m## Usability Testing[0m

[33m### All about usability testing[0m

[33m - Usability testing is one  [0m
[33m of the most commonly used UX research methods,  [0m
[33m and for good reason.  [0m
[33m Usability testing is the gold standard  [0m
[33m for evaluative research, and it's a flexible enough method  [0m
[33m to gather a variety of data.  [0m
[33m It's pretty easy to get started,  [0m
[33m but it's also easy to get caught up in some common pitfalls.  [0m
[33m I'm Amanda Stockwell.  [0m
[33m Welcome to the Usability Test Deep Dive.  [0m
[33m This course is for those of us who are already familiar  [0m
[33m with the basics of usability testing,  [0m
[33m and want to level up skills  [0m
[33m to be even more effective researchers.  [0m
[33m Join me as I discuss strategic considerations  [0m
[33m and practical tips to help you get the most out  [0m
[33m of your usability testing efforts.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Recap of usability testing[0m

[33m - A usability test is simply a tool to evaluate the ease  [0m
[33m of use of a product, service, or interface.  [0m
[33m At the core, a usability test involves observing  [0m
[33m representative users as they perform tasks,  [0m
[33m and assessing their experience and interactions.  [0m
[33m Like most UX tools, there are many variations,  [0m
[33m and it's important to understand those nuances  [0m
[33m so you can plan for your particular situation.  [0m
[33m While the general goal of usability testing  [0m
[33m is to assess usability, you might be doing so  [0m
[33m in vastly different contexts that change  [0m
[33m how you ought to plan, run, and analyze the sessions.  [0m
[33m If you're not already familiar with usability testing,  [0m
[33m now would be a great time to check out UX Foundations:  [0m
[33m Usability Testing, which covers the basics.  [0m
[33m In this course, I want to guide you through a discussion  [0m
[33m of different types of usability tests and their usage,  [0m
[33m and share things I've learned over more  [0m
[33m than a decade conducting usability tests.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m. Which Type of Test?[0m

[33m### Usability test locations[0m

[33m - Before we start diving into the specifics  [0m
[33m of running usability tests,  [0m
[33m let's take a step back to examine  [0m
[33m the types of usability tests, so we can understand  [0m
[33m the nuances and set ourselves up for success.  [0m
[33m The first variant in the usability test is location.  [0m
[33m Usability tests are traditionally conducted in person,  [0m
[33m meaning that you are physically sitting  [0m
[33m next to the participant during the session.  [0m
[33m In-person sessions have traditionally been run  [0m
[33m in a usability lab, where you have a dedicated room  [0m
[33m for the moderator and participant  [0m
[33m that has audio and video recording,  [0m
[33m and another room for observers,  [0m
[33m where the information is streamed.  [0m
[33m Yes, I'm talking the dreaded one-way mirror set up.  [0m
[33m These Labs might be at a third-party research facility,  [0m
[33m or even just a dedicated room of an office.  [0m
[33m If you don't have a lab, or need to bring the research  [0m
[33m to the participants, you might still conduct the sessions  [0m
[33m physically next to the participants.  [0m
[33m That could be as simple as sitting next to someone  [0m
[33m at their desk, or meeting them at a third-party location  [0m
[33m like a library or coworking space.  [0m
[33m You can still record audio and maybe video.  [0m
[33m It's just not quite as formal of a dedicated space.  [0m
[33m In recent years, it's also become much more possible  [0m
[33m and popular conduct usability tests remotely,  [0m
[33m meaning that you're connected digitally,  [0m
[33m but not physically present with the participants.  [0m
[33m There are many good video conferencing tools  [0m
[33m that allow you to see participants' faces  [0m
[33m and share and record the screen of any member of the party.  [0m
[33m So how to decide where to conduct sessions?  [0m
[33m Well, the answer as with most things in UX,  [0m
[33m is that it depends.  [0m
[33m Being in the same space as your participants  [0m
[33m has several benefits and is often seen as the gold standard.  [0m
[33m One large benefit is that you can more easily  [0m
[33m build rapport with participants.  [0m
[33m You can shake their hand, look them in the eye,  [0m
[33m smile and greet them.  [0m
[33m You may make a bit of small talk and be able  [0m
[33m to feel them out before you get too far into the session.  [0m
[33m More on this later.  [0m
[33m You can also observe their body language  [0m
[33m and facial expressions, which don't always match  [0m
[33m what they'll say.  [0m
[33m We'll talk more about that too.  [0m
[33m The lab setting is great for this kind of close observation  [0m
[33m and allows you to easily record audio and video  [0m
[33m so you can widely share and later revisit the sessions.  [0m
[33m It's also easier to use lower fidelity artifacts  [0m
[33m like paper prototypes if you're physically with someone  [0m
[33m and can provide some extra context.  [0m
[33m However, a lab isn't the ideal setting when the context  [0m
[33m someone is working in will greatly impact  [0m
[33m how they use something.  [0m
[33m Say you're working on improvements to a traffic  [0m
[33m and navigation app.  [0m
[33m How someone acts looking at an app while sitting  [0m
[33m at a table, may be very different than when  [0m
[33m they're trying to navigate rush hour traffic in their car.  [0m
[33m The category of research where you observe people  [0m
[33m in their own space is called ethnography.  [0m
[33m While it can create logistical challenges,  [0m
[33m it can also help you paint a richer picture  [0m
[33m of your user and how they use your product in context.  [0m
[33m If you don't have the budget to conduct formal recruiting,  [0m
[33m or don't have access to a dedicated space,  [0m
[33m you might use the guerrilla tactics of intercepting people  [0m
[33m in a public setting.  [0m
[33m Recruiting and conducting sessions in public spaces  [0m
[33m is best for when your product doesn't require  [0m
[33m particular domain expertise, you're not testing  [0m
[33m particularly sensitive material,  [0m
[33m and your budget doesn't leave you another option.  [0m
[33m On the other hand, even if you do have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to meet participants in person,  [0m
[33m remote sessions can have some advantages.  [0m
[33m The first is that remote work allows you  [0m
[33m to access participants who are geographically spread out  [0m
[33m without extra time or costs.  [0m
[33m The world is ever shrinking, and many of our products  [0m
[33m and services serve a large base of people.  [0m
[33m It's essential to be sure that you're incorporating  [0m
[33m feedback from multiple cultures, locations and contexts  [0m
[33m so as not to bias your results.  [0m
[33m Conducting sessions remotely can also save  [0m
[33m both the research team and the participant's time.  [0m
[33m You cut out commuting and set up time,  [0m
[33m and it can allow the researcher to more flexibly schedule  [0m
[33m sessions over a period of time.  [0m
[33m You could even conduct a few sessions  [0m
[33m of a research series in person and a few remotely,  [0m
[33m in order to access the participants you need.  [0m
[33m Or alternate between in-person and remote efforts  [0m
[33m depending on timing and resources.  [0m
[33m Consider switching it up occasionally to try out  [0m
[33m different methods and compare the results.  [0m
[33m Before you plan your usability test,  [0m
[33m carefully consider the context of your project  [0m
[33m and what location would be most beneficial and realistic.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Moderated vs. unmoderated usability tests[0m

[33m - Along with the option to conduct sessions remotely,  [0m
[33m more and more tools have been popping up  [0m
[33m to conduct unmoderated sessions,  [0m
[33m where you write out individual tasks for the users,  [0m
[33m and the participants complete each task on their own time.  [0m
[33m A tool provides the instructions, shows the questions,  [0m
[33m and records the actions of the user.  [0m
[33m There is no direct interaction between the participants  [0m
[33m and the researcher, which means that you need to plan  [0m
[33m unmoderated sessions even more carefully.  [0m
[33m They're also most appropriate for certain scenarios only.  [0m
[33m Because you pre-write the introduction, the core tasks,  [0m
[33m and the followup questions, unmoderated tests  [0m
[33m are best for live or very functional work  [0m
[33m that requires very little explanation.  [0m
[33m When you show a low fidelity or early stage prototype  [0m
[33m in person, you can explain limitations and provide context  [0m
[33m along the way.  [0m
[33m It's possible to navigate around known issues  [0m
[33m or work around empty areas when you moderate.  [0m
[33m Unmoderated sessions are best suited  [0m
[33m for straightforward, clear tasks  [0m
[33m that don't leave much room for interpretation,  [0m
[33m like assessing how easily someone can find  [0m
[33m a certain sort of a product on an eCommerce page,  [0m
[33m or how long it takes to check out  [0m
[33m on one site versus another.  [0m
[33m Participants are frequently put into artificial situations  [0m
[33m in usability tests anyway, but without a moderator present,  [0m
[33m it's even easier to fake things or tune out.  [0m
[33m Tasks that require emotional engagement or creativity  [0m
[33m are unlikely to get an authentic response  [0m
[33m in an unmoderated test.  [0m
[33m You also need to carefully construct the tasks  [0m
[33m to be sure they will get you the results you want.  [0m
[33m Turning goals into clear tasks already takes practice  [0m
[33m to master, and all the normal best practices apply.  [0m
[33m But writing unmoderated tasks is even more difficult.  [0m
[33m You have to explicit about you want the participant to do  [0m
[33m and when they should stop.  [0m
[33m And provide clear, specific, and realistic instructions,  [0m
[33m all without being too obvious.  [0m
[33m Make sure the tasks are written  [0m
[33m as directions, not questions.  [0m
[33m And be precise in the instruction.  [0m
[33m Let's say we were testing the LinkedIn Learning site.  [0m
[33m A good task might be something like,  [0m
[33m find a UX related LinkedIn Learning course  [0m
[33m you haven't yet watched, and stop when you get  [0m
[33m to a brief description of the course.  [0m
[33m Remember, participants won't have a chance to clarify,  [0m
[33m and you won't have a chance to probe.  [0m
[33m So if they misinterpret, the task may be wasted.  [0m
[33m It's especially important to pilot test unmoderated studies  [0m
[33m so that you can get the most authentic useful feedback.  [0m
[33m You also don't get the chance to probe,  [0m
[33m so make sure you include followup questions  [0m
[33m that are just as thoughtfully crafted.  [0m
[33m With all those limitations in mind,  [0m
[33m unmoderated studies also have some great benefits.  [0m
[33m You can run sessions in parallel and therefore collect  [0m
[33m many responses in a short amount of time.  [0m
[33m You save time and have access to a much larger  [0m
[33m and more spread out participant base  [0m
[33m than you might otherwise.  [0m
[33m You can usually offer a lower incentive  [0m
[33m to save yourself some money as well.  [0m
[33m I've used unmoderated studies to get super quick feedback  [0m
[33m from across the globe literally overnight.  [0m
[33m Everything from response to a new design direction,  [0m
[33m to interpretation of messaging options, to gut-checking  [0m
[33m which of an interaction pattern best suited our goals.  [0m
[33m These broad, quick studies have been especially useful  [0m
[33m when working in agile settings,  [0m
[33m and we needed data super fast.  [0m
[33m I also like to use unmoderated studies  [0m
[33m when I'm benchmarking and comparing the results over time.  [0m
[33m That makes it easy to set up  [0m
[33m and assures the questions remain consistent.  [0m
[33m As always, carefully consider the core goal  [0m
[33m and context of your research goals  [0m
[33m to determine the right kind of test for you.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Using usability tests to explore[0m

[33m - As we've discussed,  [0m
[33m usability tests involve observing representative users  [0m
[33m as they perform tasks.  [0m
[33m We typically think of this as evaluative research,  [0m
[33m which is meant to assess how well a solution works.  [0m
[33m We've also been discussing the need to carefully determine  [0m
[33m and craft realistic scenarios and tasks  [0m
[33m for the users to complete.  [0m
[33m But what if you don't know  [0m
[33m what tasks your users are trying to do in real life?  [0m
[33m What if you don't know what a realistic scenario is?  [0m
[33m There are other research methods  [0m
[33m like diary studies or contextual inquiries,  [0m
[33m to help you uncover user needs and behavior,  [0m
[33m but you can also modify usability test efforts  [0m
[33m to be more generative and help you learn  [0m
[33m about user's contexts.  [0m
[33m To do so, you'll remove the very defined tasks  [0m
[33m from your plan.  [0m
[33m You'll still have research goals and target areas to cover,  [0m
[33m but the tasks will be more general  [0m
[33m and more focused on hearing from the user  [0m
[33m how they accomplished a goal,  [0m
[33m than assessing a particular path for interaction.  [0m
[33m For instance, in a traditional test of an e-commerce site,  [0m
[33m you might have one task that is dedicated  [0m
[33m to assessing the search function and one that is designed  [0m
[33m to get participants to browse with categories.  [0m
[33m In a more exploratory usability test,  [0m
[33m you might ask users  [0m
[33m to generally identify a product that fits their needs  [0m
[33m and then observe which path they take,  [0m
[33m probing along the way  [0m
[33m to understand why they did it that way, what's preferable,  [0m
[33m and understand their decision-making process.  [0m
[33m You still want to understand  [0m
[33m how well the process works for them,  [0m
[33m but you're also evaluating the product or service  [0m
[33m more holistically and getting feedback  [0m
[33m about what they really do,  [0m
[33m rather than breaking it down to assess one piece at a time.  [0m
[33m Because of the need to follow up,  [0m
[33m you'll need to moderate this kind of exploratory test  [0m
[33m and be ready to be flexible during the sessions.  [0m
[33m You may end up uncovering totally new insights  [0m
[33m or discovering areas  [0m
[33m that you hadn't realized needed attention.  [0m
[33m Let's say you're working on a presentation tool  [0m
[33m and ask people to tell you about the images they include.  [0m
[33m You might've thought  [0m
[33m you wanted to explore the editing process  [0m
[33m but find out that your users  [0m
[33m actually don't really like to add pictures.  [0m
[33m Your new goal becomes to better understand that decision  [0m
[33m and learn more about their context,  [0m
[33m rather than to assess the ease of use of the feature,  [0m
[33m they wouldn't use.  [0m
[33m This sort of exploratory formative usability testing,  [0m
[33m can be done at any time there is an existing solution  [0m
[33m and you want to learn more  [0m
[33m about real behavior or motivation users have.  [0m
[33m That doesn't necessarily mean  [0m
[33m you have to test something live,  [0m
[33m but is often done in early stages of a redesign,  [0m
[33m assessment of a live product or early in the process  [0m
[33m of building something brand new.  [0m
[33m Exploratory unstructured usability testing,  [0m
[33m isn't the be-all and end-all way  [0m
[33m to understand user's contexts  [0m
[33m but it can be an extra approach in your research toolbox.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m2[0m[33m. Running the Tests[0m

[33m### Participant recruiting considerations[0m

[33m - Many people who are new to usability testing  [0m
[33m struggle most with questions about the participants.  [0m
[33m Who should you target?  [0m
[33m How many participants do you need?  [0m
[33m And how do you find them?  [0m
[33m There's plenty of material that can guide you  [0m
[33m through the basics.  [0m
[33m Understanding nuances can help you ensure  [0m
[33m you get the right people in your study,  [0m
[33m and therefore, the highest quality results for your team.  [0m
[33m One of the most common questions is who to recruit  [0m
[33m and how exact do you need to be  [0m
[33m in recruiting representative users.  [0m
[33m Lots of new researchers assume  [0m
[33m that you can include any general participant  [0m
[33m to identify usability issues.  [0m
[33m If you're working on something like voting machines  [0m
[33m or a general e-commerce site,  [0m
[33m then yes, your audience truly could be just about anyone.  [0m
[33m Maybe you just need to know which  [0m
[33m of two Add to Cart interactions is easier.  [0m
[33m Any member of the public should be able to provide you  [0m
[33m some feedback there.  [0m
[33m But more than likely, you're building something  [0m
[33m for a specific group of people  [0m
[33m who have a particular set of knowledge and experiences  [0m
[33m that impacts how they interact.  [0m
[33m Let's say you're working on a portal for medical providers  [0m
[33m to communicate context about diagnoses to their patients.  [0m
[33m Nurses and doctors are likely  [0m
[33m to use a more clinical set of language  [0m
[33m and have a deeper understanding  [0m
[33m of how to categorize ailments than a typical patient.  [0m
[33m But the portal needs to work for both type of user.  [0m
[33m Sure, a random person could give you feedback  [0m
[33m on the input part of the tool.  [0m
[33m And you'd likely identify some core issues.  [0m
[33m But you're likely going to miss nuances in the feedback  [0m
[33m that a medical professional would be able to provide.  [0m
[33m The closer your test participants are  [0m
[33m to the real users, the more authentic their feedback  [0m
[33m and higher the quality of insights you'll gain.  [0m
[33m If you have multiple different sets of user types,  [0m
[33m like the patients and providers here,  [0m
[33m make sure that you recruit participants from each group  [0m
[33m to include in your study.  [0m
[33m That leads me to my next recruiting tip,  [0m
[33m which is around the number you really need to include.  [0m
[33m You've probably heard the rule  [0m
[33m that you ought to have five users in your usability study.  [0m
[33m I'm not here to fight with that.  [0m
[33m But I want to shed a little extra light and clarity  [0m
[33m so that you can make the best choice for your work.  [0m
[33m That rule came from work that Jakob Nielson  [0m
[33m and Tom Landauer did in the '90s.  [0m
[33m They created a mathematical model that suggests  [0m
[33m you can find [0m[1;33m85[0m[33m% of usability problems  [0m
[33m after five similar participants.  [0m
[33m They suggested that instead of conducting single,  [0m
[33m large usability tests, the most effective route  [0m
[33m would be to conduct smaller, iterative studies  [0m
[33m with three to five participants each  [0m
[33m to maximize cost and benefit.  [0m
[33m If there are distinct user types,  [0m
[33m they suggest three to four participants  [0m
[33m from each category per round.  [0m
[33m Over the years, that extra contact has been lost  [0m
[33m and people just hear that five is the magic answer.  [0m
[33m Five participants is a good starting point.  [0m
[33m But please keep in mind that you will not find  [0m
[33m every issue after talking to that few participants.  [0m
[33m Furthermore, the rule only applies  [0m
[33m when you're talking about the same type of user.  [0m
[33m And if you're looking to establish baselines  [0m
[33m or compare quantitative data,  [0m
[33m you're likely going to want to increase  [0m
[33m that number even more.  [0m
[33m A good gut check on the right number of participants  [0m
[33m is feedback repetition.  [0m
[33m Once you start to hear the same thing over and over,  [0m
[33m you probably ought to spend your time addressing feedback  [0m
[33m rather than collecting more.  [0m
[33m If you have a more diverse set of users than you thought,  [0m
[33m that could be eight or [0m[1;33m10[0m[33m or even more sessions.  [0m
[33m If you start to hear all the same things  [0m
[33m after just a few participants,  [0m
[33m you can feel confident that you need to address  [0m
[33m those items first.  [0m
[33m Recruiting the right participants  [0m
[33m and getting the right sample size is key  [0m
[33m to making sure your usability sessions  [0m
[33m are the most effective for you.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Usability test logistics and preparation[0m

[33m - While it may seem obvious, carefully thinking  [0m
[33m through the logistics and small details of your study  [0m
[33m can really impact the quality of the data you gather.  [0m
[33m The schedule of the sessions is one  [0m
[33m of the easiest things for you to control,  [0m
[33m and can help make sure you get the most  [0m
[33m out of your sessions.  [0m
[33m I don't recommend more than six sessions  [0m
[33m in a day if you can help it.  [0m
[33m Moderating requires deep attention and it can be exhausting.  [0m
[33m We'll talk more about moderation tips,  [0m
[33m but schedule-wise, the most effective tactic is  [0m
[33m to spread sessions out over at least a few days.  [0m
[33m I also recommend giving yourself ample time  [0m
[33m in between sessions.  [0m
[33m You'll need this time to break for the obvious things,  [0m
[33m like snacks, but you can also use this time  [0m
[33m to take care of distractions, like email,  [0m
[33m touch base with teammates and stakeholders,  [0m
[33m and adjust anything within the test.  [0m
[33m I especially like to schedule a quick debrief  [0m
[33m with observers after each session  [0m
[33m to capture first impressions  [0m
[33m and discuss anything we might want to adjust  [0m
[33m for the next round.  [0m
[33m This built-in time also gives you wiggle room,  [0m
[33m if someone ran late or you're having trouble  [0m
[33m getting a chatty participant to wrap up.  [0m
[33m You'll also want to think through how you communicate  [0m
[33m with observers and stakeholders during the sessions.  [0m
[33m I'd always recommend recording the sessions  [0m
[33m and sharing the video with team members,  [0m
[33m but it's also good to livestream  [0m
[33m and allow others to have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to ask you questions or suggest followups in realtime.  [0m
[33m You might want to set up a group chat or text.  [0m
[33m Just make sure you don't get too distracted  [0m
[33m during the session.  [0m
[33m I recommend that observers document all their questions  [0m
[33m and notes along the way, then send one communication  [0m
[33m to the moderator to circle back to  [0m
[33m at the end of the session.  [0m
[33m Sometimes the questions end up being answered,  [0m
[33m or a new thread is uncovered, but it ensures  [0m
[33m that the stakeholders are engaged and have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to ask for followup.  [0m
[33m I'd recommend that you test this communication method  [0m
[33m while you're testing the other logistics of your study.  [0m
[33m If you're in-person, that means things  [0m
[33m like making sure the video and audio are recording correctly  [0m
[33m and placement of chairs works.  [0m
[33m If you're using a remote tool  [0m
[33m or conducting an un-moderated session,  [0m
[33m be sure to walk through all the programs and logins.  [0m
[33m No matter what, run a pilot study.  [0m
[33m This will help you double check logistical things  [0m
[33m like accounts, connections, and recording settings,  [0m
[33m catch any unclear questions or awkwardness  [0m
[33m in the question order, and get the truest sense of timing.  [0m
[33m A little extra preparation  [0m
[33m before running usability tests makes them go much smoother.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Tips for moderating effective usability sessions[0m

[33m - Effectively moderating usability tests  [0m
[33m is more art than science,  [0m
[33m and is deceptively simple-seeming.  [0m
[33m The best way to get better at running usability tests  [0m
[33m is to practice, but make sure you keep these tips in mind.  [0m
[33m It's very important to set the stage with participants  [0m
[33m and focus on building rapport early.  [0m
[33m The first few minutes of a session set the tone,  [0m
[33m so aim to help the participants feel  [0m
[33m as comfortable as they can.  [0m
[33m Clearly describe who you are, what your goal is,  [0m
[33m and what your expectations are about the session.  [0m
[33m Reiterate that you are not testing them,  [0m
[33m but you're looking for honest feedback on what works well  [0m
[33m and, more importantly, what doesn't.  [0m
[33m Let them know that you might ask follow-up questions  [0m
[33m that seem obvious, or abstain from  [0m
[33m answering their questions right away.  [0m
[33m They're free to ask for clarification,  [0m
[33m but you won't lead them down a particular path.  [0m
[33m Assuming that you aren't the one who designed  [0m
[33m what you'll be testing, let them know that you'll  [0m
[33m be passing on the feedback to the team,  [0m
[33m and that it's your job to make the overall product better.  [0m
[33m Err on the side of more explanation than not,  [0m
[33m since it's likely that participants won't  [0m
[33m be super familiar with the process,  [0m
[33m and that can be some social pressure  [0m
[33m in the situation to get things right.  [0m
[33m During the sessions, use the tasks and the test plan  [0m
[33m as a guide but not as rote text.  [0m
[33m The best feedback comes from authentic experience,  [0m
[33m so if the opportunity comes to cover a task out of order,  [0m
[33m go for it.  [0m
[33m You may also hear feedback about a related area,  [0m
[33m or unexpected path that you may want to explore.  [0m
[33m Use your judgment and don't abandon the goals of the study.  [0m
[33m But be prepared to be flexible.  [0m
[33m Actively remind yourself to relax as much as possible  [0m
[33m and allow yourself to be personable.  [0m
[33m Participants will take their social cues from you.  [0m
[33m If you appear comfortable,  [0m
[33m they will automatically be more so.  [0m
[33m Just be mindful of your reactions.  [0m
[33m For instance, if you vigorously nod when they  [0m
[33m start talking about things they like,  [0m
[33m they'll continue to do so.  [0m
[33m Try to keep a neutral expression and tone.  [0m
[33m And importantly, remember to talk as little as possible.  [0m
[33m You want to make sure the participants understand  [0m
[33m what you're asking them to do and then you want  [0m
[33m to give them space to go through,  [0m
[33m talk aloud, and work things out.  [0m
[33m Silence is uncomfortable for humans.  [0m
[33m And that's exactly the point.  [0m
[33m See?  [0m
[33m Didn't you think something was wrong?  [0m
[33m We're hardwired to want to fill empty space.  [0m
[33m You want to give the participants the opportunity  [0m
[33m to fill that space, rather than doing so yourself.  [0m
[33m This prevents you from biasing or leading the participants,  [0m
[33m and allows you to uncover new information from them.  [0m
[33m It's okay to repeat information back to participants  [0m
[33m in order to be sure you've heard them correctly.  [0m
[33m Ask for clarifications, or probe on an answer.  [0m
[33m In fact, you'll often get the most insightful information  [0m
[33m by following up on a response and getting people  [0m
[33m to explain the context behind it.  [0m
[33m Aim for open-ended questions and allow the user  [0m
[33m to guide where the discussion goes.  [0m
[33m If you get too off track, you can navigate them back  [0m
[33m with an orienting question about the original task,  [0m
[33m or prompting them to move on to the next.  [0m
[33m I highly recommend watching recorded sessions of yourself.  [0m
[33m It feels totally awkward,  [0m
[33m but even if you think you've done pretty well,  [0m
[33m you're likely to spot a place you could improve.  [0m
[33m Nearly every researcher I know has cringed through hours  [0m
[33m of watching themselves, and been able to improve their flow.  [0m
[33m When reviewing, pay attention to  [0m
[33m the ebb and flow of conversation,  [0m
[33m rather than the respondents particular answers.  [0m
[33m Notice where you jump in early, and look for areas  [0m
[33m you could've stepped back or provided more guidance.  [0m
[33m Moderating well is a tricky balance  [0m
[33m of guiding the discussion without leading  [0m
[33m to answers or getting too far off course.  [0m
[33m Give yourself time to prepare,  [0m
[33m find opportunities to practice,  [0m
[33m and constantly evaluate your sessions to improve.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m3[0m[33m. Analyzing the Test[0m

[33m### Identifying and sharing true insights[0m

[33m - Regardless of what sort of usability test your ran,  [0m
[33m you're likely to end up with a big set of raw data  [0m
[33m to analyze and synthesize into findings and recommendations.  [0m
[33m There's a lot of content out there  [0m
[33m about how to analyze usability test data,  [0m
[33m but the bigger challenge and real opportunity  [0m
[33m is in prioritizing your insights  [0m
[33m and turning them into actionable change.  [0m
[33m To help with this, I like to categorize insights  [0m
[33m by size and impact,  [0m
[33m and adjust how I present them accordingly.  [0m
[33m Very generally, I think of insights being on a continuum  [0m
[33m or immediate term practical application  [0m
[33m to longer term larger scale impact.  [0m
[33m On the immediate term end,  [0m
[33m you might have things like users expecting  [0m
[33m a different interaction for a particular pattern,  [0m
[33m or going to the wrong spot  [0m
[33m to look for something consistently.  [0m
[33m You know you can provide a tactical recommendation  [0m
[33m that would address that issue  [0m
[33m with a relatively small effort.  [0m
[33m For instance, say we were running a test  [0m
[33m on an account settings page  [0m
[33m and found that users got confused between two icons.  [0m
[33m We could recommend changing at least one of the icons  [0m
[33m and then retesting.  [0m
[33m For this sort of feedback, I clearly identified the issue,  [0m
[33m the recommendation, the next step,  [0m
[33m and then I often share directly with the team  [0m
[33m to make changes.  [0m
[33m In the right circumstances, I'll even go so far  [0m
[33m as to immediately add it to the backlog  [0m
[33m for the team who would address it.  [0m
[33m While, of course you want there to be wide visibility  [0m
[33m into what you've found,  [0m
[33m your primary goal with this sort of finding  [0m
[33m is to provide straightforward, tactical advice  [0m
[33m that the team can implement right away.  [0m
[33m On the other end of the spectrum are larger scale insights  [0m
[33m that might influence the direction  [0m
[33m of the whole product or project.  [0m
[33m You might not know an immediate solution  [0m
[33m or even know the impact,  [0m
[33m but you've gotten a clue that you need to dig deeper.  [0m
[33m For instance, you might learn that your target users  [0m
[33m can easily perform the tasks that you've asked them to do,  [0m
[33m but they report that their goals are shifting  [0m
[33m and they don't do some of those tasks anymore.  [0m
[33m In this case, there won't be straightforward recommendations  [0m
[33m for the team to take next.  [0m
[33m Instead, you're likely going to shift into advocate mode,  [0m
[33m pushing for further, deeper research  [0m
[33m to help guide the next steps.  [0m
[33m You still want to report what you've found,  [0m
[33m but you want to present the findings as a pathway to explore,  [0m
[33m not as final steps.  [0m
[33m This means the format to share your insights may change.  [0m
[33m Rather than writing a straightforward report  [0m
[33m or adding items to a backlog,  [0m
[33m you might want to make presentations to larger teams  [0m
[33m or higher level stakeholders,  [0m
[33m or schedule brainstorming sessions.  [0m
[33m Especially when presenting the sort  [0m
[33m of larger, more strategic insight,  [0m
[33m it's important to tailor the information to your audience  [0m
[33m and find ways to connect it to larger business  [0m
[33m and emotional context.  [0m
[33m This is where it might be useful  [0m
[33m to have video of a frustrated user  [0m
[33m or a sound clip declaring total disinterest.  [0m
[33m You should always be serving as the champion for the users,  [0m
[33m but insights that require further work  [0m
[33m also require further advocacy.  [0m
[33m You're also likely to have insights  [0m
[33m that fall in the middle of the spectrum.  [0m
[33m Say you've clearly identified a core usability issue  [0m
[33m but you're not sure of the design pattern to move forward  [0m
[33m and need to advocate some more solution exploration.  [0m
[33m No one kind of insight is more important than the other.  [0m
[33m It's important to understand the relative categories  [0m
[33m and be pragmatic for the situation that you're in.  [0m
[33m Remember that the format of sharing your findings  [0m
[33m is more dependent on the team and organizational structure  [0m
[33m than the type of finding.  [0m
[33m It's your job to help your team understand  [0m
[33m and utilize what you've learned in a way that makes sense.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## Conclusion[0m

[33m### Practice makes perfect[0m

[33m - Thank you so much for tuning in  [0m
[33m to my usability testing course.  [0m
[33m This course should have given you practical tips  [0m
[33m to improve your research practices,  [0m
[33m and gain the best insights from your testing efforts.  [0m
[33m If you have specific questions for me,  [0m
[33m ask in the Q&A section of this course.  [0m
[33m I may end up doing a follow up video  [0m
[33m that answers common questions.  [0m
[33m And know that this is just one  [0m
[33m of a series of deep dives into research best practices.  [0m
[33m So be on the lookout for other courses  [0m
[33m to improve your research endeavors.  [0m
[33m As with all research,  [0m
[33m the best way to improve is to practice.  [0m
[33m So get out there and start testing.  [0m
[33m [0m
