[34m# Tools Mentioned in [0m[34m"UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing"[0m[34m Course[0m

[34mBased on a careful analysis of the transcript, the following tools are mentioned either explicitly or implicitly:[0m

[34m## Video/Conferencing Tools[0m
[34m- Video conferencing tools [0m[1;34m([0m[34mmentioned generally for remote usability testing[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Screen sharing software [0m[1;34m([0m[34mfor recording participant screens during remote sessions[0m[1;34m)[0m

[34m## Research Facilities/Setups[0m
[34m- Usability labs with one-way mirrors[0m
[34m- Audio and video recording equipment[0m
[34m- Third-party research facilities[0m

[34m## Remote/Unmoderated Testing Tools[0m
[34m- Unmoderated usability testing platforms [0m[1;34m([0m[34mmentioned generally without specific names[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Tools that provide instructions, show questions, and record user actions[0m

[34m## Communication Tools[0m
[34m- Group chat or text messaging [0m[1;34m([0m[34mfor observer communication during tests[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Livestreaming tools [0m[1;34m([0m[34mfor stakeholders to observe sessions in real-time[0m[1;34m)[0m

[34m## Documentation/Analysis Tools[0m
[34m- Recording/playback tools [0m[1;34m([0m[34mfor reviewing moderator performance[0m[1;34m)[0m
[34m- Backlog tracking systems [0m[1;34m([0m[34mfor adding issues discovered during testing[0m[1;34m)[0m

[34mThe transcript discusses these tools in general terms without mentioning specific brand names or platforms. The focus is more on the methodology and best[0m
[34mpractices rather than specific technology recommendations.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36muser:[0m
[33mlook at this transcript from a video course:::::   [0m[1;33m{[0m[1;33m{[0m[1;33m3.[0m[33mtranscript[0m[1;33m}[0m[1;33m}[0m[33m :::::::::: does it mention UserTesting?[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36muser:[0m
[33mlook at this transcript from a video course:::::   [0m[1;33m<[0m[1;33mcourse[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course_title>[0m
[33mUX Deep Dive: Usability Testing[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<course_transcript>[0m
[33m# UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing[0m

[33m## Usability Testing[0m

[33m### All about usability testing[0m

[33m - Usability testing is one  [0m
[33m of the most commonly used UX research methods,  [0m
[33m and for good reason.  [0m
[33m Usability testing is the gold standard  [0m
[33m for evaluative research, and it's a flexible enough method  [0m
[33m to gather a variety of data.  [0m
[33m It's pretty easy to get started,  [0m
[33m but it's also easy to get caught up in some common pitfalls.  [0m
[33m I'm Amanda Stockwell.  [0m
[33m Welcome to the Usability Test Deep Dive.  [0m
[33m This course is for those of us who are already familiar  [0m
[33m with the basics of usability testing,  [0m
[33m and want to level up skills  [0m
[33m to be even more effective researchers.  [0m
[33m Join me as I discuss strategic considerations  [0m
[33m and practical tips to help you get the most out  [0m
[33m of your usability testing efforts.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Recap of usability testing[0m

[33m - A usability test is simply a tool to evaluate the ease  [0m
[33m of use of a product, service, or interface.  [0m
[33m At the core, a usability test involves observing  [0m
[33m representative users as they perform tasks,  [0m
[33m and assessing their experience and interactions.  [0m
[33m Like most UX tools, there are many variations,  [0m
[33m and it's important to understand those nuances  [0m
[33m so you can plan for your particular situation.  [0m
[33m While the general goal of usability testing  [0m
[33m is to assess usability, you might be doing so  [0m
[33m in vastly different contexts that change  [0m
[33m how you ought to plan, run, and analyze the sessions.  [0m
[33m If you're not already familiar with usability testing,  [0m
[33m now would be a great time to check out UX Foundations:  [0m
[33m Usability Testing, which covers the basics.  [0m
[33m In this course, I want to guide you through a discussion  [0m
[33m of different types of usability tests and their usage,  [0m
[33m and share things I've learned over more  [0m
[33m than a decade conducting usability tests.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m. Which Type of Test?[0m

[33m### Usability test locations[0m

[33m - Before we start diving into the specifics  [0m
[33m of running usability tests,  [0m
[33m let's take a step back to examine  [0m
[33m the types of usability tests, so we can understand  [0m
[33m the nuances and set ourselves up for success.  [0m
[33m The first variant in the usability test is location.  [0m
[33m Usability tests are traditionally conducted in person,  [0m
[33m meaning that you are physically sitting  [0m
[33m next to the participant during the session.  [0m
[33m In-person sessions have traditionally been run  [0m
[33m in a usability lab, where you have a dedicated room  [0m
[33m for the moderator and participant  [0m
[33m that has audio and video recording,  [0m
[33m and another room for observers,  [0m
[33m where the information is streamed.  [0m
[33m Yes, I'm talking the dreaded one-way mirror set up.  [0m
[33m These Labs might be at a third-party research facility,  [0m
[33m or even just a dedicated room of an office.  [0m
[33m If you don't have a lab, or need to bring the research  [0m
[33m to the participants, you might still conduct the sessions  [0m
[33m physically next to the participants.  [0m
[33m That could be as simple as sitting next to someone  [0m
[33m at their desk, or meeting them at a third-party location  [0m
[33m like a library or coworking space.  [0m
[33m You can still record audio and maybe video.  [0m
[33m It's just not quite as formal of a dedicated space.  [0m
[33m In recent years, it's also become much more possible  [0m
[33m and popular conduct usability tests remotely,  [0m
[33m meaning that you're connected digitally,  [0m
[33m but not physically present with the participants.  [0m
[33m There are many good video conferencing tools  [0m
[33m that allow you to see participants' faces  [0m
[33m and share and record the screen of any member of the party.  [0m
[33m So how to decide where to conduct sessions?  [0m
[33m Well, the answer as with most things in UX,  [0m
[33m is that it depends.  [0m
[33m Being in the same space as your participants  [0m
[33m has several benefits and is often seen as the gold standard.  [0m
[33m One large benefit is that you can more easily  [0m
[33m build rapport with participants.  [0m
[33m You can shake their hand, look them in the eye,  [0m
[33m smile and greet them.  [0m
[33m You may make a bit of small talk and be able  [0m
[33m to feel them out before you get too far into the session.  [0m
[33m More on this later.  [0m
[33m You can also observe their body language  [0m
[33m and facial expressions, which don't always match  [0m
[33m what they'll say.  [0m
[33m We'll talk more about that too.  [0m
[33m The lab setting is great for this kind of close observation  [0m
[33m and allows you to easily record audio and video  [0m
[33m so you can widely share and later revisit the sessions.  [0m
[33m It's also easier to use lower fidelity artifacts  [0m
[33m like paper prototypes if you're physically with someone  [0m
[33m and can provide some extra context.  [0m
[33m However, a lab isn't the ideal setting when the context  [0m
[33m someone is working in will greatly impact  [0m
[33m how they use something.  [0m
[33m Say you're working on improvements to a traffic  [0m
[33m and navigation app.  [0m
[33m How someone acts looking at an app while sitting  [0m
[33m at a table, may be very different than when  [0m
[33m they're trying to navigate rush hour traffic in their car.  [0m
[33m The category of research where you observe people  [0m
[33m in their own space is called ethnography.  [0m
[33m While it can create logistical challenges,  [0m
[33m it can also help you paint a richer picture  [0m
[33m of your user and how they use your product in context.  [0m
[33m If you don't have the budget to conduct formal recruiting,  [0m
[33m or don't have access to a dedicated space,  [0m
[33m you might use the guerrilla tactics of intercepting people  [0m
[33m in a public setting.  [0m
[33m Recruiting and conducting sessions in public spaces  [0m
[33m is best for when your product doesn't require  [0m
[33m particular domain expertise, you're not testing  [0m
[33m particularly sensitive material,  [0m
[33m and your budget doesn't leave you another option.  [0m
[33m On the other hand, even if you do have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to meet participants in person,  [0m
[33m remote sessions can have some advantages.  [0m
[33m The first is that remote work allows you  [0m
[33m to access participants who are geographically spread out  [0m
[33m without extra time or costs.  [0m
[33m The world is ever shrinking, and many of our products  [0m
[33m and services serve a large base of people.  [0m
[33m It's essential to be sure that you're incorporating  [0m
[33m feedback from multiple cultures, locations and contexts  [0m
[33m so as not to bias your results.  [0m
[33m Conducting sessions remotely can also save  [0m
[33m both the research team and the participant's time.  [0m
[33m You cut out commuting and set up time,  [0m
[33m and it can allow the researcher to more flexibly schedule  [0m
[33m sessions over a period of time.  [0m
[33m You could even conduct a few sessions  [0m
[33m of a research series in person and a few remotely,  [0m
[33m in order to access the participants you need.  [0m
[33m Or alternate between in-person and remote efforts  [0m
[33m depending on timing and resources.  [0m
[33m Consider switching it up occasionally to try out  [0m
[33m different methods and compare the results.  [0m
[33m Before you plan your usability test,  [0m
[33m carefully consider the context of your project  [0m
[33m and what location would be most beneficial and realistic.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Moderated vs. unmoderated usability tests[0m

[33m - Along with the option to conduct sessions remotely,  [0m
[33m more and more tools have been popping up  [0m
[33m to conduct unmoderated sessions,  [0m
[33m where you write out individual tasks for the users,  [0m
[33m and the participants complete each task on their own time.  [0m
[33m A tool provides the instructions, shows the questions,  [0m
[33m and records the actions of the user.  [0m
[33m There is no direct interaction between the participants  [0m
[33m and the researcher, which means that you need to plan  [0m
[33m unmoderated sessions even more carefully.  [0m
[33m They're also most appropriate for certain scenarios only.  [0m
[33m Because you pre-write the introduction, the core tasks,  [0m
[33m and the followup questions, unmoderated tests  [0m
[33m are best for live or very functional work  [0m
[33m that requires very little explanation.  [0m
[33m When you show a low fidelity or early stage prototype  [0m
[33m in person, you can explain limitations and provide context  [0m
[33m along the way.  [0m
[33m It's possible to navigate around known issues  [0m
[33m or work around empty areas when you moderate.  [0m
[33m Unmoderated sessions are best suited  [0m
[33m for straightforward, clear tasks  [0m
[33m that don't leave much room for interpretation,  [0m
[33m like assessing how easily someone can find  [0m
[33m a certain sort of a product on an eCommerce page,  [0m
[33m or how long it takes to check out  [0m
[33m on one site versus another.  [0m
[33m Participants are frequently put into artificial situations  [0m
[33m in usability tests anyway, but without a moderator present,  [0m
[33m it's even easier to fake things or tune out.  [0m
[33m Tasks that require emotional engagement or creativity  [0m
[33m are unlikely to get an authentic response  [0m
[33m in an unmoderated test.  [0m
[33m You also need to carefully construct the tasks  [0m
[33m to be sure they will get you the results you want.  [0m
[33m Turning goals into clear tasks already takes practice  [0m
[33m to master, and all the normal best practices apply.  [0m
[33m But writing unmoderated tasks is even more difficult.  [0m
[33m You have to explicit about you want the participant to do  [0m
[33m and when they should stop.  [0m
[33m And provide clear, specific, and realistic instructions,  [0m
[33m all without being too obvious.  [0m
[33m Make sure the tasks are written  [0m
[33m as directions, not questions.  [0m
[33m And be precise in the instruction.  [0m
[33m Let's say we were testing the LinkedIn Learning site.  [0m
[33m A good task might be something like,  [0m
[33m find a UX related LinkedIn Learning course  [0m
[33m you haven't yet watched, and stop when you get  [0m
[33m to a brief description of the course.  [0m
[33m Remember, participants won't have a chance to clarify,  [0m
[33m and you won't have a chance to probe.  [0m
[33m So if they misinterpret, the task may be wasted.  [0m
[33m It's especially important to pilot test unmoderated studies  [0m
[33m so that you can get the most authentic useful feedback.  [0m
[33m You also don't get the chance to probe,  [0m
[33m so make sure you include followup questions  [0m
[33m that are just as thoughtfully crafted.  [0m
[33m With all those limitations in mind,  [0m
[33m unmoderated studies also have some great benefits.  [0m
[33m You can run sessions in parallel and therefore collect  [0m
[33m many responses in a short amount of time.  [0m
[33m You save time and have access to a much larger  [0m
[33m and more spread out participant base  [0m
[33m than you might otherwise.  [0m
[33m You can usually offer a lower incentive  [0m
[33m to save yourself some money as well.  [0m
[33m I've used unmoderated studies to get super quick feedback  [0m
[33m from across the globe literally overnight.  [0m
[33m Everything from response to a new design direction,  [0m
[33m to interpretation of messaging options, to gut-checking  [0m
[33m which of an interaction pattern best suited our goals.  [0m
[33m These broad, quick studies have been especially useful  [0m
[33m when working in agile settings,  [0m
[33m and we needed data super fast.  [0m
[33m I also like to use unmoderated studies  [0m
[33m when I'm benchmarking and comparing the results over time.  [0m
[33m That makes it easy to set up  [0m
[33m and assures the questions remain consistent.  [0m
[33m As always, carefully consider the core goal  [0m
[33m and context of your research goals  [0m
[33m to determine the right kind of test for you.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Using usability tests to explore[0m

[33m - As we've discussed,  [0m
[33m usability tests involve observing representative users  [0m
[33m as they perform tasks.  [0m
[33m We typically think of this as evaluative research,  [0m
[33m which is meant to assess how well a solution works.  [0m
[33m We've also been discussing the need to carefully determine  [0m
[33m and craft realistic scenarios and tasks  [0m
[33m for the users to complete.  [0m
[33m But what if you don't know  [0m
[33m what tasks your users are trying to do in real life?  [0m
[33m What if you don't know what a realistic scenario is?  [0m
[33m There are other research methods  [0m
[33m like diary studies or contextual inquiries,  [0m
[33m to help you uncover user needs and behavior,  [0m
[33m but you can also modify usability test efforts  [0m
[33m to be more generative and help you learn  [0m
[33m about user's contexts.  [0m
[33m To do so, you'll remove the very defined tasks  [0m
[33m from your plan.  [0m
[33m You'll still have research goals and target areas to cover,  [0m
[33m but the tasks will be more general  [0m
[33m and more focused on hearing from the user  [0m
[33m how they accomplished a goal,  [0m
[33m than assessing a particular path for interaction.  [0m
[33m For instance, in a traditional test of an e-commerce site,  [0m
[33m you might have one task that is dedicated  [0m
[33m to assessing the search function and one that is designed  [0m
[33m to get participants to browse with categories.  [0m
[33m In a more exploratory usability test,  [0m
[33m you might ask users  [0m
[33m to generally identify a product that fits their needs  [0m
[33m and then observe which path they take,  [0m
[33m probing along the way  [0m
[33m to understand why they did it that way, what's preferable,  [0m
[33m and understand their decision-making process.  [0m
[33m You still want to understand  [0m
[33m how well the process works for them,  [0m
[33m but you're also evaluating the product or service  [0m
[33m more holistically and getting feedback  [0m
[33m about what they really do,  [0m
[33m rather than breaking it down to assess one piece at a time.  [0m
[33m Because of the need to follow up,  [0m
[33m you'll need to moderate this kind of exploratory test  [0m
[33m and be ready to be flexible during the sessions.  [0m
[33m You may end up uncovering totally new insights  [0m
[33m or discovering areas  [0m
[33m that you hadn't realized needed attention.  [0m
[33m Let's say you're working on a presentation tool  [0m
[33m and ask people to tell you about the images they include.  [0m
[33m You might've thought  [0m
[33m you wanted to explore the editing process  [0m
[33m but find out that your users  [0m
[33m actually don't really like to add pictures.  [0m
[33m Your new goal becomes to better understand that decision  [0m
[33m and learn more about their context,  [0m
[33m rather than to assess the ease of use of the feature,  [0m
[33m they wouldn't use.  [0m
[33m This sort of exploratory formative usability testing,  [0m
[33m can be done at any time there is an existing solution  [0m
[33m and you want to learn more  [0m
[33m about real behavior or motivation users have.  [0m
[33m That doesn't necessarily mean  [0m
[33m you have to test something live,  [0m
[33m but is often done in early stages of a redesign,  [0m
[33m assessment of a live product or early in the process  [0m
[33m of building something brand new.  [0m
[33m Exploratory unstructured usability testing,  [0m
[33m isn't the be-all and end-all way  [0m
[33m to understand user's contexts  [0m
[33m but it can be an extra approach in your research toolbox.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m2[0m[33m. Running the Tests[0m

[33m### Participant recruiting considerations[0m

[33m - Many people who are new to usability testing  [0m
[33m struggle most with questions about the participants.  [0m
[33m Who should you target?  [0m
[33m How many participants do you need?  [0m
[33m And how do you find them?  [0m
[33m There's plenty of material that can guide you  [0m
[33m through the basics.  [0m
[33m Understanding nuances can help you ensure  [0m
[33m you get the right people in your study,  [0m
[33m and therefore, the highest quality results for your team.  [0m
[33m One of the most common questions is who to recruit  [0m
[33m and how exact do you need to be  [0m
[33m in recruiting representative users.  [0m
[33m Lots of new researchers assume  [0m
[33m that you can include any general participant  [0m
[33m to identify usability issues.  [0m
[33m If you're working on something like voting machines  [0m
[33m or a general e-commerce site,  [0m
[33m then yes, your audience truly could be just about anyone.  [0m
[33m Maybe you just need to know which  [0m
[33m of two Add to Cart interactions is easier.  [0m
[33m Any member of the public should be able to provide you  [0m
[33m some feedback there.  [0m
[33m But more than likely, you're building something  [0m
[33m for a specific group of people  [0m
[33m who have a particular set of knowledge and experiences  [0m
[33m that impacts how they interact.  [0m
[33m Let's say you're working on a portal for medical providers  [0m
[33m to communicate context about diagnoses to their patients.  [0m
[33m Nurses and doctors are likely  [0m
[33m to use a more clinical set of language  [0m
[33m and have a deeper understanding  [0m
[33m of how to categorize ailments than a typical patient.  [0m
[33m But the portal needs to work for both type of user.  [0m
[33m Sure, a random person could give you feedback  [0m
[33m on the input part of the tool.  [0m
[33m And you'd likely identify some core issues.  [0m
[33m But you're likely going to miss nuances in the feedback  [0m
[33m that a medical professional would be able to provide.  [0m
[33m The closer your test participants are  [0m
[33m to the real users, the more authentic their feedback  [0m
[33m and higher the quality of insights you'll gain.  [0m
[33m If you have multiple different sets of user types,  [0m
[33m like the patients and providers here,  [0m
[33m make sure that you recruit participants from each group  [0m
[33m to include in your study.  [0m
[33m That leads me to my next recruiting tip,  [0m
[33m which is around the number you really need to include.  [0m
[33m You've probably heard the rule  [0m
[33m that you ought to have five users in your usability study.  [0m
[33m I'm not here to fight with that.  [0m
[33m But I want to shed a little extra light and clarity  [0m
[33m so that you can make the best choice for your work.  [0m
[33m That rule came from work that Jakob Nielson  [0m
[33m and Tom Landauer did in the '90s.  [0m
[33m They created a mathematical model that suggests  [0m
[33m you can find [0m[1;33m85[0m[33m% of usability problems  [0m
[33m after five similar participants.  [0m
[33m They suggested that instead of conducting single,  [0m
[33m large usability tests, the most effective route  [0m
[33m would be to conduct smaller, iterative studies  [0m
[33m with three to five participants each  [0m
[33m to maximize cost and benefit.  [0m
[33m If there are distinct user types,  [0m
[33m they suggest three to four participants  [0m
[33m from each category per round.  [0m
[33m Over the years, that extra contact has been lost  [0m
[33m and people just hear that five is the magic answer.  [0m
[33m Five participants is a good starting point.  [0m
[33m But please keep in mind that you will not find  [0m
[33m every issue after talking to that few participants.  [0m
[33m Furthermore, the rule only applies  [0m
[33m when you're talking about the same type of user.  [0m
[33m And if you're looking to establish baselines  [0m
[33m or compare quantitative data,  [0m
[33m you're likely going to want to increase  [0m
[33m that number even more.  [0m
[33m A good gut check on the right number of participants  [0m
[33m is feedback repetition.  [0m
[33m Once you start to hear the same thing over and over,  [0m
[33m you probably ought to spend your time addressing feedback  [0m
[33m rather than collecting more.  [0m
[33m If you have a more diverse set of users than you thought,  [0m
[33m that could be eight or [0m[1;33m10[0m[33m or even more sessions.  [0m
[33m If you start to hear all the same things  [0m
[33m after just a few participants,  [0m
[33m you can feel confident that you need to address  [0m
[33m those items first.  [0m
[33m Recruiting the right participants  [0m
[33m and getting the right sample size is key  [0m
[33m to making sure your usability sessions  [0m
[33m are the most effective for you.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Usability test logistics and preparation[0m

[33m - While it may seem obvious, carefully thinking  [0m
[33m through the logistics and small details of your study  [0m
[33m can really impact the quality of the data you gather.  [0m
[33m The schedule of the sessions is one  [0m
[33m of the easiest things for you to control,  [0m
[33m and can help make sure you get the most  [0m
[33m out of your sessions.  [0m
[33m I don't recommend more than six sessions  [0m
[33m in a day if you can help it.  [0m
[33m Moderating requires deep attention and it can be exhausting.  [0m
[33m We'll talk more about moderation tips,  [0m
[33m but schedule-wise, the most effective tactic is  [0m
[33m to spread sessions out over at least a few days.  [0m
[33m I also recommend giving yourself ample time  [0m
[33m in between sessions.  [0m
[33m You'll need this time to break for the obvious things,  [0m
[33m like snacks, but you can also use this time  [0m
[33m to take care of distractions, like email,  [0m
[33m touch base with teammates and stakeholders,  [0m
[33m and adjust anything within the test.  [0m
[33m I especially like to schedule a quick debrief  [0m
[33m with observers after each session  [0m
[33m to capture first impressions  [0m
[33m and discuss anything we might want to adjust  [0m
[33m for the next round.  [0m
[33m This built-in time also gives you wiggle room,  [0m
[33m if someone ran late or you're having trouble  [0m
[33m getting a chatty participant to wrap up.  [0m
[33m You'll also want to think through how you communicate  [0m
[33m with observers and stakeholders during the sessions.  [0m
[33m I'd always recommend recording the sessions  [0m
[33m and sharing the video with team members,  [0m
[33m but it's also good to livestream  [0m
[33m and allow others to have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to ask you questions or suggest followups in realtime.  [0m
[33m You might want to set up a group chat or text.  [0m
[33m Just make sure you don't get too distracted  [0m
[33m during the session.  [0m
[33m I recommend that observers document all their questions  [0m
[33m and notes along the way, then send one communication  [0m
[33m to the moderator to circle back to  [0m
[33m at the end of the session.  [0m
[33m Sometimes the questions end up being answered,  [0m
[33m or a new thread is uncovered, but it ensures  [0m
[33m that the stakeholders are engaged and have the opportunity  [0m
[33m to ask for followup.  [0m
[33m I'd recommend that you test this communication method  [0m
[33m while you're testing the other logistics of your study.  [0m
[33m If you're in-person, that means things  [0m
[33m like making sure the video and audio are recording correctly  [0m
[33m and placement of chairs works.  [0m
[33m If you're using a remote tool  [0m
[33m or conducting an un-moderated session,  [0m
[33m be sure to walk through all the programs and logins.  [0m
[33m No matter what, run a pilot study.  [0m
[33m This will help you double check logistical things  [0m
[33m like accounts, connections, and recording settings,  [0m
[33m catch any unclear questions or awkwardness  [0m
[33m in the question order, and get the truest sense of timing.  [0m
[33m A little extra preparation  [0m
[33m before running usability tests makes them go much smoother.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m### Tips for moderating effective usability sessions[0m

[33m - Effectively moderating usability tests  [0m
[33m is more art than science,  [0m
[33m and is deceptively simple-seeming.  [0m
[33m The best way to get better at running usability tests  [0m
[33m is to practice, but make sure you keep these tips in mind.  [0m
[33m It's very important to set the stage with participants  [0m
[33m and focus on building rapport early.  [0m
[33m The first few minutes of a session set the tone,  [0m
[33m so aim to help the participants feel  [0m
[33m as comfortable as they can.  [0m
[33m Clearly describe who you are, what your goal is,  [0m
[33m and what your expectations are about the session.  [0m
[33m Reiterate that you are not testing them,  [0m
[33m but you're looking for honest feedback on what works well  [0m
[33m and, more importantly, what doesn't.  [0m
[33m Let them know that you might ask follow-up questions  [0m
[33m that seem obvious, or abstain from  [0m
[33m answering their questions right away.  [0m
[33m They're free to ask for clarification,  [0m
[33m but you won't lead them down a particular path.  [0m
[33m Assuming that you aren't the one who designed  [0m
[33m what you'll be testing, let them know that you'll  [0m
[33m be passing on the feedback to the team,  [0m
[33m and that it's your job to make the overall product better.  [0m
[33m Err on the side of more explanation than not,  [0m
[33m since it's likely that participants won't  [0m
[33m be super familiar with the process,  [0m
[33m and that can be some social pressure  [0m
[33m in the situation to get things right.  [0m
[33m During the sessions, use the tasks and the test plan  [0m
[33m as a guide but not as rote text.  [0m
[33m The best feedback comes from authentic experience,  [0m
[33m so if the opportunity comes to cover a task out of order,  [0m
[33m go for it.  [0m
[33m You may also hear feedback about a related area,  [0m
[33m or unexpected path that you may want to explore.  [0m
[33m Use your judgment and don't abandon the goals of the study.  [0m
[33m But be prepared to be flexible.  [0m
[33m Actively remind yourself to relax as much as possible  [0m
[33m and allow yourself to be personable.  [0m
[33m Participants will take their social cues from you.  [0m
[33m If you appear comfortable,  [0m
[33m they will automatically be more so.  [0m
[33m Just be mindful of your reactions.  [0m
[33m For instance, if you vigorously nod when they  [0m
[33m start talking about things they like,  [0m
[33m they'll continue to do so.  [0m
[33m Try to keep a neutral expression and tone.  [0m
[33m And importantly, remember to talk as little as possible.  [0m
[33m You want to make sure the participants understand  [0m
[33m what you're asking them to do and then you want  [0m
[33m to give them space to go through,  [0m
[33m talk aloud, and work things out.  [0m
[33m Silence is uncomfortable for humans.  [0m
[33m And that's exactly the point.  [0m
[33m See?  [0m
[33m Didn't you think something was wrong?  [0m
[33m We're hardwired to want to fill empty space.  [0m
[33m You want to give the participants the opportunity  [0m
[33m to fill that space, rather than doing so yourself.  [0m
[33m This prevents you from biasing or leading the participants,  [0m
[33m and allows you to uncover new information from them.  [0m
[33m It's okay to repeat information back to participants  [0m
[33m in order to be sure you've heard them correctly.  [0m
[33m Ask for clarifications, or probe on an answer.  [0m
[33m In fact, you'll often get the most insightful information  [0m
[33m by following up on a response and getting people  [0m
[33m to explain the context behind it.  [0m
[33m Aim for open-ended questions and allow the user  [0m
[33m to guide where the discussion goes.  [0m
[33m If you get too off track, you can navigate them back  [0m
[33m with an orienting question about the original task,  [0m
[33m or prompting them to move on to the next.  [0m
[33m I highly recommend watching recorded sessions of yourself.  [0m
[33m It feels totally awkward,  [0m
[33m but even if you think you've done pretty well,  [0m
[33m you're likely to spot a place you could improve.  [0m
[33m Nearly every researcher I know has cringed through hours  [0m
[33m of watching themselves, and been able to improve their flow.  [0m
[33m When reviewing, pay attention to  [0m
[33m the ebb and flow of conversation,  [0m
[33m rather than the respondents particular answers.  [0m
[33m Notice where you jump in early, and look for areas  [0m
[33m you could've stepped back or provided more guidance.  [0m
[33m Moderating well is a tricky balance  [0m
[33m of guiding the discussion without leading  [0m
[33m to answers or getting too far off course.  [0m
[33m Give yourself time to prepare,  [0m
[33m find opportunities to practice,  [0m
[33m and constantly evaluate your sessions to improve.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## [0m[1;33m3[0m[33m. Analyzing the Test[0m

[33m### Identifying and sharing true insights[0m

[33m - Regardless of what sort of usability test your ran,  [0m
[33m you're likely to end up with a big set of raw data  [0m
[33m to analyze and synthesize into findings and recommendations.  [0m
[33m There's a lot of content out there  [0m
[33m about how to analyze usability test data,  [0m
[33m but the bigger challenge and real opportunity  [0m
[33m is in prioritizing your insights  [0m
[33m and turning them into actionable change.  [0m
[33m To help with this, I like to categorize insights  [0m
[33m by size and impact,  [0m
[33m and adjust how I present them accordingly.  [0m
[33m Very generally, I think of insights being on a continuum  [0m
[33m or immediate term practical application  [0m
[33m to longer term larger scale impact.  [0m
[33m On the immediate term end,  [0m
[33m you might have things like users expecting  [0m
[33m a different interaction for a particular pattern,  [0m
[33m or going to the wrong spot  [0m
[33m to look for something consistently.  [0m
[33m You know you can provide a tactical recommendation  [0m
[33m that would address that issue  [0m
[33m with a relatively small effort.  [0m
[33m For instance, say we were running a test  [0m
[33m on an account settings page  [0m
[33m and found that users got confused between two icons.  [0m
[33m We could recommend changing at least one of the icons  [0m
[33m and then retesting.  [0m
[33m For this sort of feedback, I clearly identified the issue,  [0m
[33m the recommendation, the next step,  [0m
[33m and then I often share directly with the team  [0m
[33m to make changes.  [0m
[33m In the right circumstances, I'll even go so far  [0m
[33m as to immediately add it to the backlog  [0m
[33m for the team who would address it.  [0m
[33m While, of course you want there to be wide visibility  [0m
[33m into what you've found,  [0m
[33m your primary goal with this sort of finding  [0m
[33m is to provide straightforward, tactical advice  [0m
[33m that the team can implement right away.  [0m
[33m On the other end of the spectrum are larger scale insights  [0m
[33m that might influence the direction  [0m
[33m of the whole product or project.  [0m
[33m You might not know an immediate solution  [0m
[33m or even know the impact,  [0m
[33m but you've gotten a clue that you need to dig deeper.  [0m
[33m For instance, you might learn that your target users  [0m
[33m can easily perform the tasks that you've asked them to do,  [0m
[33m but they report that their goals are shifting  [0m
[33m and they don't do some of those tasks anymore.  [0m
[33m In this case, there won't be straightforward recommendations  [0m
[33m for the team to take next.  [0m
[33m Instead, you're likely going to shift into advocate mode,  [0m
[33m pushing for further, deeper research  [0m
[33m to help guide the next steps.  [0m
[33m You still want to report what you've found,  [0m
[33m but you want to present the findings as a pathway to explore,  [0m
[33m not as final steps.  [0m
[33m This means the format to share your insights may change.  [0m
[33m Rather than writing a straightforward report  [0m
[33m or adding items to a backlog,  [0m
[33m you might want to make presentations to larger teams  [0m
[33m or higher level stakeholders,  [0m
[33m or schedule brainstorming sessions.  [0m
[33m Especially when presenting the sort  [0m
[33m of larger, more strategic insight,  [0m
[33m it's important to tailor the information to your audience  [0m
[33m and find ways to connect it to larger business  [0m
[33m and emotional context.  [0m
[33m This is where it might be useful  [0m
[33m to have video of a frustrated user  [0m
[33m or a sound clip declaring total disinterest.  [0m
[33m You should always be serving as the champion for the users,  [0m
[33m but insights that require further work  [0m
[33m also require further advocacy.  [0m
[33m You're also likely to have insights  [0m
[33m that fall in the middle of the spectrum.  [0m
[33m Say you've clearly identified a core usability issue  [0m
[33m but you're not sure of the design pattern to move forward  [0m
[33m and need to advocate some more solution exploration.  [0m
[33m No one kind of insight is more important than the other.  [0m
[33m It's important to understand the relative categories  [0m
[33m and be pragmatic for the situation that you're in.  [0m
[33m Remember that the format of sharing your findings  [0m
[33m is more dependent on the team and organizational structure  [0m
[33m than the type of finding.  [0m
[33m It's your job to help your team understand  [0m
[33m and utilize what you've learned in a way that makes sense.  [0m
[33m [0m


[33m## Conclusion[0m

[33m### Practice makes perfect[0m

[33m - Thank you so much for tuning in  [0m
[33m to my usability testing course.  [0m
[33m This course should have given you practical tips  [0m
[33m to improve your research practices,  [0m
[33m and gain the best insights from your testing efforts.  [0m
[33m If you have specific questions for me,  [0m
[33m ask in the Q&A section of this course.  [0m
[33m I may end up doing a follow up video  [0m
[33m that answers common questions.  [0m
[33m And know that this is just one  [0m
[33m of a series of deep dives into research best practices.  [0m
[33m So be on the lookout for other courses  [0m
[33m to improve your research endeavors.  [0m
[33m As with all research,  [0m
[33m the best way to improve is to practice.  [0m
[33m So get out there and start testing.  [0m
[33m [0m

[1;36massistant:[0m
[34mThe curriculum appears well-structured, but there could be some overlap and areas where a more focused approach might make sense, particularly with [0m
[34mcourses like [0m[34m"UX Research Methods: Interviewing"[0m[34m and [0m[34m"Data-Driven Product Research and Design."[0m[34m Here is the order of courses in the proposed corrected [0m
[34msequence:[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **UX Foundations: Research** - Provides an overview of UX research methodologies, types of tests, and best practices.[0m
[1;34m2[0m[34m. **UX Research Methods: Interviewing** - Specifically focuses on improving skills in conducting interviews, which may build directly off the broader [0m
[34mfoundational knowledge from the first course.[0m
[1;34m3[0m[34m. **UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing** - Offers a deep dive into usability testing techniques and methodologies specific to user experience design [0m
[34mprojects.[0m
[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Remote User Testing with UserTesting.com** - Provides practical insights into conducting effective remote user tests, which builds on the general [0m
[34mresearch skills discussed in previous courses.[0m
[1;34m5[0m[34m. **Agile UX Research** - Integrates UX research practices within an agile development framework.[0m
[1;34m6[0m[34m. **Practical A/B Testing** - Focuses specifically on setting up and analyzing A/B tests for digital products.[0m
[1;34m7[0m[34m. **UX Foundations: Analyzing User Data** - Teaches how to synthesize collected data into valuable insights, useful after researchers have gathered [0m
[34msufficient user data from interviews and usability tests.[0m

[34mConsidering the overlap between [0m[34m"Data-Driven Product Research and Design"[0m[34m [0m[1;34m([0m[34mwhich broadly covers identifying challenges, recruiting participants, planning[0m
[34msessions etc.[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m and foundational knowledge covered in the introductory [0m[34m"UX Foundations: Research,"[0m[34m it might be reasonable to remove the latter for more [0m
[34mfocused learning experience. [0m

[34mHowever, if data-driven research is crucial content that isn't adequately covered by other courses, it may still remain.[0m

[34m**Recommendation:**[0m

[34m- Remove **UX Foundations: Analyzing User Data**.[0m
[34m- Add a course on [0m[34m"Inclusive UX Research"[0m[34m or [0m[34m"Ethics in UX Research,"[0m[34m which could fit naturally between [0m[34m"UX Deep Dive: Usability Testing"[0m[34m and [0m[34m"Remote [0m
[34mUser Testing with UserTesting.com."[0m

[34mThis would streamline the curriculum while ensuring comprehensive coverage.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36muser:[0m
[33mYou are an L&D administrator at a large enterprise organization, and regularly create curricula for various professional audiences. [0m

[33mHere are some examples of how you map out the audience for a given curriculum:[0m

[33m================================[0m
[1;33m1[0m[33m. Early career people considering a Customer Success career path.[0m
[1;33m2[0m[33m. People currently in customer service roles and who are looking to leverage their skills to move into more specialized customer success[0m
[33mpositions.[0m
[1;33m3[0m[33m. People in adjacent roles who want/need to embrace a service mindset[0m

[33mBeginning web developers or programmers without experience in Javascript[0m

[33mSofware developers and DevOps Engineers[0m

[33mDevOps Engineers, and developer [0m[33m/[0m[33m IT needing a basic understanding of DevOps practices[0m

[33mDevelopers and architects who need to skill up on designing, building, and migrating systems to a microservices architecture.[0m

[33mThis audience is a little different from the Python certificate audience. While Python is a [0m[33m"gateway drug"[0m[33m to programming for a very wide[0m
[33maudience, people who are interested in C++ are likely higher intent to be software developers. As such, this certificate presumes some [0m
[33mbasic conversational knowledge with programming, and ramps up more quickly from beginner to advanced topics.[0m
[33mThree personas:[0m
[33m* Beginners who want to start learning C++ programming from scratch and quickly progress to writing their own programs and applications.[0m
[33m* Existing C++ programmers who want to take their skills to the next level by mastering more advanced concepts, techniques, and best [0m
[33mpractices.[0m
[33m* Developers coming from other programming languages who need to get up to speed with C++ syntax, fundamentals, and common design [0m
[33mpatterns.[0m

[33mNurses who are keen to grow into mgmt positions[0m
[33m================================[0m

[33mLook at this list of course titles and descriptions for a new curriculum:[0m

[33m================================[0m
[33m**Accounting Foundations**: Learn accounting. Get an introduction to the four basic types: financial accounting, managerial accounting, [0m
[33mincome tax accounting, and bookkeeping.[0m
[33m**Financial Accounting Part [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m**: Find out how to use financial data to drive strategic decision-making. Learn the basics of financial [0m
[33maccounting, including analyzing and preparing financial statements.[0m
[33m**Financial Accounting Part [0m[1;33m2[0m[33m**: Take a deeper dive into the world of financial accounting. Learn about financial ratio analysis, [0m
[33mforecasting financial statements, cash flow analysis, and more.[0m

[33m================================[0m

[33mHow would you describe the audience for this learning path? Your answer should not be longer than [0m[1;33m100[0m[33m words. Only return the audience [0m
[33mdescription, no titles or headers.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36massistant:[0m
[34mFinancial professionals at the start of their careers, students pursuing accounting or finance degrees, or individuals in adjacent roles [0m
[34mseeking to build foundational accounting knowledge. This path also serves employees who need to understand financial statements for [0m
[34mbusiness decisions, professionals transitioning into accounting roles, and those preparing for entry-level accounting positions. The [0m
[34mcurriculum assumes minimal prior accounting knowledge but progresses to intermediate concepts suitable for those wanting to advance their[0m
[34mfinancial analysis skills.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36massistant:[0m
[34m# Ideal Course Sequence and Redundancy Analysis[0m

[34mAfter analyzing the curriculum, here's the ideal sequence and identification of redundant courses:[0m

[34m## Ideal Course Sequence[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Everyday AI Concepts**[0m
[34m   * Provides foundational understanding of AI concepts including machine learning, predictive AI, and generative AI[0m
[34m   * Introduces legal and ethical considerations[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Introduction to Prompt Engineering for Generative AI**[0m
[34m   * Builds technical skills for working with AI tools[0m
[34m   * Introduces large language models and practical applications[0m

[1;34m3[0m[34m. **A Content Marketer's Guide to Responsible AI**[0m
[34m   * Transitions from general AI knowledge to marketing-specific applications[0m
[34m   * Emphasizes ethical implementation and bias mitigation[0m

[1;34m4[0m[34m. **Generative AI for Digital Marketers**[0m
[34m   * Develops strategic thinking for AI implementation in marketing[0m
[34m   * Introduces evaluation processes for AI tools[0m

[1;34m5[0m[34m. **Writing Great Content with Gen AI That Doesn't Sound Fake**[0m
[34m   * Focused application for content creation with authenticity[0m
[34m   * Practical prompt crafting and editing skills[0m

[1;34m6[0m[34m. **Build Your Generative AI Plan for Marketing Success**[0m
[34m   * Culminating course for developing comprehensive AI strategy[0m
[34m   * Real-world implementation planning and strategic decision-making[0m

[34m## Courses to Remove [0m[1;34m([0m[34mRedundant Content[0m[1;34m)[0m

[1;34m1[0m[34m. **Marketing Tools: How to Leverage AI Tools to Transform Your Marketing**[0m
[34m   * Content overlaps significantly with [0m[34m"Generative AI for Digital Marketers"[0m
[34m   * Both cover tool evaluation, content creation, and marketing workflow integration[0m

[1;34m2[0m[34m. **Using Generative AI across the Marketing Lifecycle**[0m
[34m   * Content duplicates material from [0m[34m"Build Your Generative AI Plan for Marketing Success"[0m
[34m   * Both address generative AI applications across marketing functions and ethical considerations[0m

[34mThis sequence creates a logical progression from fundamental concepts to specialized applications, while eliminating redundancy that would otherwise cause learner fatigue.[0m

[1;32m──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m

[33m## Introduction[0m

[33mthe effectiveness of AI systems like ChatGPT.[0m

[33m## [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m. Prompting Techniques[0m
[33m        [0m[33mReference prompting     [0m[1;33m327[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe easiest way to get more accurate answers from an AI system like ChatGPT is by providing [0m
[33mreference material. This video shows you how.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mZero-shot and few-shot prompting        [0m[1;33m200[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to use zero-shot and few-shot prompting to help ChatGPT and other AI[0m
[33msystems recognize patterns and produce consistent outputs.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mChain-of-thought [0m[1;33m([0m[33mCoT[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m prompting        [0m[1;33m319[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to use Chain-of-Thought [0m[1;33m([0m[33mCoT[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m prompting to get ChatGPT to reason its[0m
[33mway thorugh complex problems.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mTake a deep breath and work step by step        [0m[1;33m168[0m[33m     [0m[33mTelling ChatGPT to [0m[33m"take a deep breath and go step by step"[0m[33m [0m
[33mdramatically improves its performance. Learn how to do this and why it works in this video.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mGenerated knowledge prompting   [0m[1;33m185[0m[33m     [0m[33mGenerate Knowledge Prompting means using ChatGPT to generate patterns and information [0m
[33mit can use in later prompts. It's a very effective advanced prompt engineering technique.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mTree-of-thought [0m[1;33m([0m[33mToT[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m prompting [0m[1;33m201[0m[33m     [0m[33mA highly effective advanced prompt engineering technique is Tree-of-Thought [0m[1;33m([0m[33mToT[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m. [0m
[33mLearn how to get ChatGPT to generate multiple strategies for solving a problem and pick the best one.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mDirectional stimulus prompting  [0m[1;33m177[0m[33m     [0m[33mOne of the best ways of getting ChatGPT to produce more accurate summaries is by [0m
[33mgiving it a hint about what you want. This is called Directional Stimulus Prompting [0m[1;33m([0m[33mDSP[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m and you'll learn how to do it in this video.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mChain-of-density [0m[1;33m([0m[33mCoD[0m[1;33m)[0m[33m prompting        [0m[1;33m340[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to get ChatGPT and other AI systems to generate advanced and highly [0m
[33maccurate summaries of text by checking its own work across multiple rounds. This advanced prompt engineering technique is called [0m
[33mChain-of-Density prompting.[0m

[1;36muser:[0m
[33mYou are an L&D administrator at a large enterprise organization, and regularly create curricula for various [0m
[33mprofessional audiences. [0m

[33mHere are some examples of how you map out the audience for a given curriculum:[0m

[33m================================[0m
[1;33m1[0m[33m. Early career people considering a Customer Success career path.[0m
[1;33m2[0m[33m. People currently in customer service roles and who are looking to leverage their skills to move into more [0m
[33mspecialized customer success positions.[0m
[1;33m3[0m[33m. People in adjacent roles who want/need to embrace a service mindset[0m

[33mBeginning web developers or programmers without experience in Javascript[0m

[33mSofware developers and DevOps Engineers[0m

[33mDevOps Engineers, and developer [0m[33m/[0m[33m IT needing a basic understanding of DevOps practices[0m

[33mDevelopers and architects who need to skill up on designing, building, and migrating systems to a microservices [0m
[33marchitecture.[0m

[33mThis audience is a little different from the Python certificate audience. While Python is a [0m[33m"gateway drug"[0m[33m to [0m
[33mprogramming for a very wide audience, people who are interested in C++ are likely higher intent to be software [0m
[33mdevelopers. As such, this certificate presumes some basic conversational knowledge with programming, and ramps up more [0m
[33mquickly from beginner to advanced topics.[0m
[33mThree personas:[0m
[33m* Beginners who want to start learning C++ programming from scratch and quickly progress to writing their own programs [0m
[33mand applications.[0m
[33m* Existing C++ programmers who want to take their skills to the next level by mastering more advanced concepts, [0m
[33mtechniques, and best practices.[0m
[33m* Developers coming from other programming languages who need to get up to speed with C++ syntax, fundamentals, and [0m
[33mcommon design patterns.[0m

[33mNurses who are keen to grow into mgmt positions[0m

[33mBelow is a table of contents for a course on the topic of How to Find Sales Leads.[0m

[1;33m<[0m[1;33mcourse_toc[0m[33m>[0m
[33m# How to Find Sales Leads[0m
[33m## Introduction[0m
[33m        [0m[33mIntroduction    [0m[1;33m90[0m[33m      [0m[33mAs sales professionals, you need to generate new leads from somewhere. In this video, explore where to start [0m
[33mand how to build a comprehensive list of whom to prospect to maximize your sales.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWhy is this important?  [0m[1;33m89[0m[33m      [0m[33mFinding new leads to prospect is the most important step of the sales process. In this video, learn how[0m
[33mto identify a good lead and how to build your list of prospects.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mBe prepared     [0m[1;33m138[0m[33m     [0m[33mBefore you can go searching for great leads, you should be prepared. Let's define the parameters of a good lead[0m
[33mto avoid wasting your own time.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m. Getting Started[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWhy start with businesses?      [0m[1;33m117[0m[33m     [0m[33mBefore you hone in on individuals to contact, you should start with a list of businesses to [0m
[33mtarget. In this video, learn why you should work at the business to business level to cast a wide net before narrowing it down.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mUse search engines      [0m[1;33m116[0m[33m     [0m[33mYour favorite search engine is one of the first tools you should use when identifying prospective [0m
[33mbusinesses. In this video, explore the parameters of these searches.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mUse the news    [0m[1;33m149[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe news can put new businesses on your radar and drop prospective leads into your laps. In this video, learn [0m
[33mwhat details to watch for and the best sources of news to monitor.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mApproach to your network        [0m[1;33m133[0m[33m     [0m[33mSuccess is more likely when you use your network and define the parameters of the types of [0m
[33mbusinesses you're seeking. In this video, learn what details to provide or request when reaching out to your network.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWebsites        [0m[1;33m133[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe internet is an incredibly powerful tool to help you find businesses to prospect. In this video, learn which[0m
[33mwebsites are most useful in your sales process.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mGet creative    [0m[1;33m174[0m[33m     [0m[33mCreativity is important when building your prospective business list. In this video, learn how to ask different[0m
[33mquestions and search with different parameters than your competitors. Discover the unusual places you can find new business names.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m2[0m[33m. Finding Leads[0m
[33m        [0m[33mUse LinkedIn    [0m[1;33m98[0m[33m      [0m[33mLinkedIn can help you gather more detailed information about who performs which roles in a business. In this [0m
[33mvideo, learn exactly what types of data can be gleaned from this resource.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mSearch engines  [0m[1;33m141[0m[33m     [0m[33mSearch engines are a tool for finding more detailed information about roles within a business. In this video, [0m
[33mlearn how this asset and social media can assist you.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mTry the news    [0m[1;33m133[0m[33m     [0m[33mBreaking news may allow target businesses to organically reveal themselves to you. In this video, learn how [0m
[33mmonitoring the daily news, setting alerts for specific businesses, and choosing mediums carefully can help you stay one step ahead of your [0m
[33mcompetitors.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mUtilize your network    [0m[1;33m123[0m[33m     [0m[33mAsking your existing customers for leads is a part of networking that so many salespeople forget. In [0m
[33mthis video, learn what specific questions to ask customers to garner leads.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mTry existing customers  [0m[1;33m201[0m[33m     [0m[33mWithin existing customer businesses, there are specific individuals to contact to gather more [0m
[33minformation for leads. In this video, learn how to initiate requests with receptionists, office managers, and departing employees, as well as [0m
[33mhow to initiate requests about roles listed in old CRM notes.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mRemain creative [0m[1;33m87[0m[33m      [0m[33mOnce you have built your prospective business list, you should get in contact with them. In this video, learn [0m
[33mhow to convert leads into opportunities through cold calling, cold emailing, and knocking on doors after researching to find contact details.[0m
[33m## Conclusion[0m
[33m        [0m[33mConclusion      [0m[1;33m98[0m[33m      [0m[33mThis course covers setting parameters for businesses desired, finding businesses, and finding ideal individuals[0m
[33mat the companies with whom you should begin building relationships. In this video, review the best tools for accomplishing these tasks, [0m
[33mincluding LinkedIn, your own networks, the news, and your own creativity.[0m

[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_toc[0m[1;33m>[0m

[33mPlease analyze the TOC and then imagine this is the first course in a series of [0m[1;33m5[0m[33m-[0m[1;33m8[0m[33m courses. [0m
[33mThink about how this intro course might be setting the scene for the courses to come. What topics would those courses be on?[0m
[33mPlease design the entire curriculum for this series of courses. Remember to include [0m[1;33m5[0m[33m-[0m[1;33m8[0m[33m modules, each with a title and description.[0m

[33mIMPORTANT: YOU SHOULD INCLUDE THE COURSE YOU'VE BEEN GIVEN AS THE FIRST COURSE IN YOUR CURRICULUM.[0m

[1;32m─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [0mMessage[1;32m ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────[0m
[1;36massistant:[0m
[34mtopic[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Sales Lead Generation and Management'[0m[34m [0m[34mmodules[0m[34m=[0m[1;34m[[0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'How to Find Sales Leads'[0m[34m, [0m[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m'This foundational module focuses on [0m
[34mthe critical skill of identifying and generating new sales leads. Beginning with the importance of lead generation in the sales process, [0m
[34mparticipants learn how to define parameters for quality leads before wasting valuable time. The course covers multiple sources for finding [0m
[34mpotential businesses, including search engines, news monitoring, networking approaches, and specialized websites. Participants then dive deeper[0m
[34minto finding specific individuals within target companies through LinkedIn, creative search techniques, and leveraging existing customer [0m
[34mrelationships. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on developing systematic approaches to lead generation while maintaining creativity to[0m
[34mstay ahead of competitors. By the conclusion, sales professionals will have a comprehensive understanding of the lead generation process and [0m
[34mpractical tools to build robust prospect lists.'[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Qualifying and Prioritizing Sales Prospects'[0m[34m, [0m[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m"Building[0m[34m on the [0m
[34mfoundation of lead generation, this module teaches sales professionals how to effectively qualify and prioritize prospects to maximize [0m
[34mconversion rates and efficiency. Participants learn to develop ideal customer profiles and buyer personas that align with their organization's [0m
[34mproducts or services. The course introduces various qualification frameworks such as BANT [0m[34m([0m[34mBudget, Authority, Need, Timeline[0m[34m)[0m[34m and MEDDIC [0m
[34m([0m[34mMetrics, Economic Buyer, Decision Criteria, Decision Process, Identify Pain, Champion[0m[34m)[0m[34m, showing when each is most effective. Through practical[0m
[34mexercises, sales professionals discover how to conduct effective discovery calls, ask strategic questions that reveal buying potential, and [0m
[34midentify red flags that suggest poor prospect fit. The module also covers how to score leads based on engagement metrics, analyze digital [0m
[34mfootprints for buying signals, and create prioritization systems that focus efforts on high-potential opportunities while maintaining nurturing[0m
[34mstrategies for longer-term prospects."[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Effective Sales Outreach Strategies'[0m[34m, [0m[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m'This comprehensive module equips [0m
[34msales professionals with proven techniques for initiating meaningful connections with prospects. Participants learn to craft compelling value [0m
[34mpropositions tailored to specific industries and persona types, ensuring relevance in every communication. The course explores the psychology [0m
[34mof prospect engagement, teaching professionals how to overcome initial resistance and build rapport quickly. Special attention is given to [0m
[34mdeveloping multi-channel outreach sequences that combine email, phone, social media, and video prospecting for maximum effectiveness. Sales [0m
[34mprofessionals master the art of personalization at scale, learning how to research prospects efficiently while creating messages that feel [0m
[34mindividually crafted. The module also covers timing strategies for outreach, analyzing optimal contact cadences, and measuring response rates [0m
[34macross different approaches. By completion, participants will have developed a systematic approach to sales outreach that balances [0m
[34mpersonalization with scalability while significantly improving connection rates.'[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Building and Managing a Sales Pipeline'[0m[34m, [0m
[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m"This[0m[34m strategic module focuses on constructing and maintaining a healthy sales pipeline that converts leads into revenue. [0m
[34mParticipants learn to design pipeline stages that accurately reflect their company's sales process, establishing clear criteria for movement [0m
[34mbetween stages. The course covers pipeline metrics that matter most, teaching professionals how to calculate and interpret velocity, conversion[0m
[34mrates, and average deal sizes to identify bottlenecks. Sales professionals discover how to forecast accurately using pipeline data, giving [0m
[34mleadership visibility into expected results while identifying early warning signs of potential shortfalls. The module explores effective [0m
[34mpipeline review practices, coaching conversations, and accountability systems that prevent deals from stagnating. Participants also learn [0m
[34mpipeline management technology best practices, ensuring their CRM becomes a powerful tool rather than an administrative burden. By mastering [0m
[34mpipeline management, sales professionals gain control over their sales process, improve forecasting accuracy, and systematically increase close[0m
[34mrates across their prospect portfolio."[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Relationship Building and Account Development'[0m[34m, [0m[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m"This[0m[34m advanced module [0m
[34mshifts focus from acquisition to growth, teaching sales professionals how to nurture relationships that yield long-term value. Participants [0m
[34mlearn strategic account mapping techniques that identify key stakeholders, power structures, and potential expansion opportunities within [0m
[34mclient organizations. The course covers relationship development across various touchpoints, from formal business reviews to informal [0m
[34mrelationship maintenance. Sales professionals master consultative approaches that position them as trusted advisors rather than transactional [0m
[34mvendors, learning to identify business challenges beyond immediate product needs. The module teaches effective cross-selling and upselling [0m
[34mstrategies that expand account footprint while delivering genuine value to clients. Participants also develop skills in creating account growth[0m
[34mplans with measurable objectives, action steps, and success metrics. By implementing these relationship development techniques, sales [0m
[34mprofessionals transform from hunters to farmers, building stable revenue streams through expanded client relationships while reducing the [0m
[34morganization's dependence on constant new business acquisition."[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Sales Analytics and Performance Optimization'[0m[34m, [0m
[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m"This[0m[34m data-driven module empowers sales professionals to leverage analytics for continuous performance improvement. Participants [0m
[34mlearn to identify and track the most meaningful metrics for their specific sales environment, moving beyond basic activity counts to [0m
[34mimpact-focused measurements. The course introduces practical approaches to sales data visualization that highlight patterns and opportunities [0m
[34mthat might otherwise remain hidden. Sales professionals discover how to conduct effective win/loss analyses that reveal systemic strengths and [0m
[34mweaknesses in their approaches. The module covers benchmarking techniques that contextualize performance against industry standards and [0m
[34minternal peers, helping professionals set appropriate improvement targets. Participants also learn to establish personal dashboards that focus [0m
[34mdaily activities on the metrics most likely to drive success. The course concludes with strategies for creating feedback loops that enable [0m
[34mcontinuous refinement of sales approaches based on data insights. By embracing analytics, sales professionals gain clarity on what's working, [0m
[34mwhat isn't, and where to focus improvement efforts."[0m[1;34m)[0m[34m, [0m[1;34mModule[0m[1;34m([0m[34mtitle[0m[34m=[0m[34m'Advanced Sales Technology and Automation'[0m[34m, [0m[34mdescription[0m[34m=[0m[34m'This [0m

[33mefficiency in processing data.[0m
[33m        [0m[1;33many[0m[1;33m([0m[1;33m)[0m[33m and [0m[1;33mall[0m[1;33m([0m[1;33m)[0m[33m functions in Python     [0m[1;33m234[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to use the [0m[1;33many[0m[1;33m([0m[1;33m)[0m[33m and [0m[1;33mall[0m[1;33m([0m[1;33m)[0m[33m functions for boolean evaluation. [33museful for logical operations in code.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m10[0m[33m. Logging in Python[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWhat is logging?        [0m[1;33m279[0m[33m     [0m[33mGrasp the concept of logging for capturing runtime information. This is important for [0m
[33mdebugging and monitoring.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCustom logging  [0m[1;33m289[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to customize logging behavior for specific requirements. This enhances flexibility in [0m
[33mlogging setup.[0m

[33mand maintainability.[0m

[33mPython Statistics Essential Training[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mcourse_title[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<description>[0m
[33mThe field of statistics has become increasingly dependent on data analysis and interpretation using Python. With the rise of big data [0m
[33mand data science, the demand for professionals who can effectively analyze and interpret data using Python has skyrocketed. In this [0m
[33mcourse, Matt Harrison teaches you how to collect, clean, analyze, and visualize data using the powerful tools of the Python [0m
[33mprogramming language. Join Matt as he gives into the various techniques that form the backbone of statistics and helps you understand [0m
[33mthe data with summary statistics and visualizations. He explains how to create predictive models using both linear regression [0m
[33mandXGBoost, and wraps up the course with a look at hypothesis testing.If youâ€™re interested in exploring statistics using a [0m
[33mcode-first approach, join Matt in this course as he shows you how to use Python to unlock the power of data.[0m
[33m<[0m[33m/[0m[33mdescription[0m[33m>[0m
[33m<toc>[0m
[33m# Python Statistics Essential Training[0m
[33m## Introduction[0m
[33m        [0m[33mBeing a Python statistics MVP   [0m[1;33m50[0m[33m      [0m[33mIn this video, explore a compelling example of the topic in action and learn how to [0m
[33muse this space to grab the browsing learner. The TOC and course description exist on the course's home page to communicate what's in [0m
[33mthe course and who it's for.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWhat you should know    [0m[1;33m41[0m[33m      [0m[33mIn this video, discover any use of GitHub or other project tools employed in the course.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mUsing GitHub Codespaces with this course        [0m[1;33m186[0m[33m     [0m[33mIn this video, learn how to use Codespaces with the course.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m1[0m[33m. Loading and Cleaning Data[0m
[33m        [0m[33mLoading data    [0m[1;33m328[0m[33m     [0m[33mWith the skill of loading data with Pandas, you can easily read data from various file formats such as[0m
[33mCSV, Excel, SQL databases, and more, manipulate and clean data using Pandas' powerful tools, perform data analysis and exploration, [0m
[33mand prepare data for modeling and visualization. Pandas is widely used in the data science community, making it a valuable skill for [0m
[33manyone working with data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mStrings and categories  [0m[1;33m959[0m[33m     [0m[33mWith the skill of cleaning categorical data, you can ensure that the data is accurate and [0m
[33mconsistent, which is critical for making meaningful analyses and predictions. You can also effectively handle missing values, [0m
[33moutliers, and other anomalies in the data, which can improve the accuracy of your models and prevent biased results.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCleaning numbers        [0m[1;33m957[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe goal of this video is to learn how to clean numbers by handling missing values, handling [0m
[33moutliers, and addressing inconsistencies in the data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mShrinking numbers       [0m[1;33m350[0m[33m     [0m[33mWith the skill of cleaning integer data, you can ensure that the data is accurate and [0m
[33mconsistent, which is critical for making meaningful analyses and predictions. Also, learn how to lower the memory requirements if [0m
[33mpossible.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mChallenge: Clean Ames   [0m[1;33m97[0m
[33m        [0m[33mSolution: Clean Ames    [0m[1;33m263[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m2[0m[33m. Exploring and Visualizing[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCategorical exploration [0m[1;33m242[0m[33m     [0m[33mWith the skill of calculating and interpreting summary statistics, you can gain valuable [0m
[33minsights into the central tendency, variability, and distribution of your data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mHistograms and distributions    [0m[1;33m262[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe goal of this video is to learn how to create and interpret histograms, which are [0m
[33mgraphical representations of the distribution of numerical data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mOutliers and Z-scores   [0m[1;33m412[0m[33m     [0m[33mDiscover how you can objectively identify data points that are significantly different from [0m
[33mthe majority of the data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCorrelations    [0m[1;33m422[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to identify relationships between variables, determine the strength and direction of those [0m
[33mrelationships, and make informed decisions based on the data.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mScatter plots   [0m[1;33m457[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to create and interpret scatter plots, which are graphical representations of the [0m
[33mrelationship between two variables.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mVisualizing categorical and numerical values    [0m[1;33m642[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to calculate and interpret numerical summaries of data based[0m
[33mon categorical variables, such as means or medians of groups.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mComparing two categoricals      [0m[1;33m362[0m
[33m        [0m[33mChallenge: Explore Ames [0m[1;33m27[0m
[33m        [0m[33mSolution: Explore Ames  [0m[1;33m208[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m3[0m[33m. Linear Regressions[0m
[33m        [0m[33mLinear regression       [0m[1;33m441[0m[33m     [0m[33mLinear regression is commonly used in data analysis and can help you identify significant [0m
[33mpredictors of a target variable, as well as their effect size and direction.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mInterpreting linear regression models   [0m[1;33m260[0m[33m     [0m[33mBy interpreting the coefficients, you can understand the magnitude and [0m
[33mdirection of the effect of each independent variable on the dependent variable.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mStandardizing values    [0m[1;33m382[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe goal of this video is to learn how to standardize variables, which involves transforming [0m
[33mvariables to have a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mRegression with XGBoost [0m[1;33m522[0m[33m     [0m[33mThe goal of this video is to learn how to build and interpret a regression model using [0m
[33mXGBoost, which is a popular algorithm for gradient boosting.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mChallenge: Predict Ames [0m[1;33m40[0m

[33m        [0m[33mSummarizing categorical data    [0m[1;33m619[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to define elements of a plot. This video covers object-oriented plotting, [0m
[33msub-plots, and axis labels.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mPearson correlation analysis    [0m[1;33m893[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to conduct parametic correlation analysis via Pearson correlation. This [0m
[33mvideo covers linear correlation and causation.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mSpearman rank correlation and Chi-square        [0m[1;33m888[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to conduct non-parametric correlation analysis. This video [0m
[33mcovers categorical variables, Spearman rank correlation, and Chi-square tables.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mExtreme value analysis for outliers     [0m[1;33m839[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to conduct extreme value analysis for outliers. This video covers [0m
[33mpoint outliers, contextual outliers, and collective outliers.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mMultivariate analysis for outliers      [0m[1;33m467[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to conduct multivariate analysis for outliers. This video covers box[0m
[33mplots and scatter plot matrices.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m6[0m[33m. Getting Started with Machine Learning[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCleaning and treating categorical variables     [0m[1;33m648[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn about categorical encoding including one-hot, binary, and [0m
[33mvectorizations.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mTransforming data set distributions     [0m[1;33m415[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to transform data set distributions. This video covers preparing [0m
[33mdata for machine learning, normalization, and standardization.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mApplied machine learning: Starter problem       [0m[1;33m532[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to use the data in a ML problem by formatting predictors and[0m
[33mlabels, and then passing them to a simple ML algorithm.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m7[0m[33m. Data Sourcing via Web Scraping[0m
[33m        [0m[33mIntroduction of web scraping    [0m[1;33m145[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn about data scraping from web sources to obtain data from multiple online [0m
[33msources. Learn why web scraping is needed in data science.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mPython requests for automating data collection  [0m[1;33m577[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn about the basics of the requests library, how connections are [0m
[33mestablished, response headers, body, content-types, and metadata extraction.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mBeautifulSoup object    [0m[1;33m1144[0m[33m    [0m[33mLearn how to work with objects. This video covers the Beautiful Soup library and BeautifulSoup[0m
[33mobjects.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mNavigableString objects [0m[1;33m660[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to work with objects. This video covers the NavigableString objects.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mData parsing    [0m[1;33m837[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to parse data. This video covers parsing data, getting data from a parse tree, and searching[0m
[33mand retrieving data from a parse tree.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mWeb scraping in practice        [0m[1;33m792[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to scrape web data. This video covers reading and writing data from the [0m
[33minternet.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mAsynchronous scraping   [0m[1;33m1236[0m[33m    [0m[33mLearn about writing parallelized scrapers with asyncio.[0m
[33m## [0m[1;33m8[0m[33m. Collaborative Analytics with Streamlit[0m
[33m        [0m[33mIntroduction to Streamlit       [0m[1;33m314[0m[33m     [0m[33mGet introduced to the spectrum of dashboarding utilities for Python, including [0m
[33mStreamlit, Voila, Panel, and Dash. Learn why Streamlit is preferable.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mEnvironment setup       [0m[1;33m168[0m[33m     [0m[33mGet a basic introduction to Streamlit and how to import the required packages.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCreate basic charts     [0m[1;33m546[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to create basic charts in Streamlit, including a simple line chart, bar chart, and [0m
[33mpie chart.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mLine charts in Streamlit        [0m[1;33m522[0m[33m     [0m[33mExplore various options for displaying line charts in Streamlit.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mBar charts and pie charts in Streamlit  [0m[1;33m691[0m[33m     [0m[33mExplore various options for displaying pie charts and bar charts in Streamlit.[0m
[33m        [0m[33mCreate statistical charts       [0m[1;33m515[0m[33m     [0m[33mLearn how to create statistical charts in Streamlit. This video covers histograms, [0m
[33mboxplots, and scatter plots.[0m

[33munderstanding of data libraries and data manipulation. Along the way, get an introduction to exploratory data analysis, data cleaning,[0m
